publicationStmt.publisher: Henry Porter, fl. 1599 (d.1599) The Pleasant History Of, the two angry women of Abington. With the humorous mirth of Dicke Coomes and Nicholas Prouerbes, two Seruingmen. as it was lately playde by the right Honourable the Earle of Nottingham, Lord high Admirall his seruants. By Henry Porter London Imprinted ... for William Ferbrand [etc.] 1599

titlePage.titlePart:
The pleasant Comedy of the
two angrie Women of
Abington.

div2.stage:
Enter Maister Goursey and his wife, and Maister Barnes
and his wife, with their two sonnes and their two seruants.

sp.speaker: Maister Goursey.
sp.l: Good master Barnes, this entertain of yours,
So full of courtesy and rich delight:
Makes me misdoubt my poor ability,
In quittance of this friendly courtesy.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O master Goursie, neighbour amity,
Is such a jewel of high reckoned worth:
As for the attain of it, what would not I
Disburse, it is so precious in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: M. Gor.
sp.l: Kind sir, near dwelling amity indeed,
Offers the hearts enquiry better view,
Than love that is seated in a farther soil,
As prospectives the nearer that they be,
Yield better judgment to the judging eye,
Things seen far off, are lessened in the eye,
When their true shape is seen being hard by.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: True sir, it is so, and truly I esteem
Mere amity, familiar neighbourhood,
The cousin germaine unto wedded love.

sp.speaker: M. Gor.
sp.l: Aye sir, there is surely some alliance twixt them,
For they have both the offspring from the heart,
Within the hearts blood Ocean still are found,
Jewels of amity, and Gems of love.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Aye master Goursey, I have in my time,
Seen many shipwrecks of true honesty,
But incident such dangers ever are,
To them that without compass sail so far.
Why what need men to swim when they may wade?
But leave this talk, enough of this is said,
And Master Goursey, in good faith sir welcome:
And mistress Goursey, I am much in debt,
unto your kindness that would visit me.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou
sp.l: O master Barnes, you put me but in mind,
Of that which I should say, it is we that are
Indebted to your kindness for this cheer:
Which debt that we may repay, I pray let us have
Sometimes your company, at our homely house.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: That mistress Goursie you shall surely have,
He will be a bold guest I warrant ye,
And bolder too with you, than I would have him.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: How do ye mean he will be bold with me?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Why he will trouble you at home forsooth,
Often call in, and ask ye how ye do:
And sit and chat with you all day till night,
And all night too, if he might have his will.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Aye wife indeed, I thank her for her kindness,
She hath made me much good cheer passing that way.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Passing well done of her, she is a kind wench,
I thank ye, Mistress Goursey for my husband:
And if it hap your husband come our way
Ahunting, or such ordinary sports,
I will do as much for yours, as you for mine.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Pray do forsooth, Gods Lord what means the woman,
She speaks it scornfully, Ifaith I care not,
Things are well spoken, if they be well taken.
What mistress Barnes, is it not time to part?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: What is aclocke sirrah?

sp.speaker: Nicholas.
sp.l: It is but new struck one.

sp.speaker: The Prologue.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I come to ye like one
that lacks and would borrow, but
was loath to ask least he should be
denied: I would ask, but I would
ask to obtain: O would I knew that manner
of asking: to beg were base, and to couch low
and to carry an humble show of entreaty, were
too Dog-like that fawns on his master to get
a bone from his Trencher: out Cur I cannot
abide it, to put on the shape and habit of this
new worlds newfound beggars, mistermed
Soldiers, as thus: sweet Gentlemen, let a poor
Scholar implore and exerate, that you would
make him rich in the possession of a mite of
your favours, to keep him a true man in wit,
and to pay for his lodging among the Muses:
so God him help he is driven to a most low
estate, it is not unknown what service of words
he hath been at, he lost his limbs in a
late conflict of flout, a brave repulse and a
hot assault it was, he doth protest, as EVER he
saw since he knew what the report of a volley
of Jests were, he shall therefore desire you: A
plague upon it, each Beadle disdained, would
whip him from your company. Well Gentlemen,
I cannot tell how to get your favours better
than by desert: then the worse luck, or the
worse wit or somewhat, for I shall not now
deserve it. Well then, I commit myself to my
fortunes, and your contents, contented to die,
if your severe judgments shall judge me to be
stung to death with the Adders hiss.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Well to your game, we will not trouble ye.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Where stands your man now?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Doth he not stand right?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: It stands between the points.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: And that is my spite.
But yet methinks the dice runs much uneven,
That I throw but deuce ace and you eleven

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: And yet you see that I cast down the hill,

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Aye, I beshrew ye, it is not with my will.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Do ye beshrew me?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: No I beshrew the dice,
That turn you up more at once, than me at twice.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou
sp.l: Well, you shall see them turn for you anon.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: But I care not for them when your game is don.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: My game, what game?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Your game, your game at tables.

sp.speaker: Mis. Go.
sp.l: Well mistress, well, I have red AEsops fables,
And know your morals meaning well enough.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Lo, you will be angry, now here is good stuff

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: How now women, who hath won the game?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Nobodie yet.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Your wife is the fairest for it.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: in your eye.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: He holds your fairer for it than I.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: For what forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Good gamester, for your game.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Well, try it out, it is all but in the bearing.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Nay if it come to bearing, she will be best,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Why, you are as good a bearer as the rest.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Nay thatis not so, you bear one man too many.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Better do so than bear not any.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Beshrew me, but my wifes jests grow too bitter.
Plainer speeches for her were more better,
Malice lies enboweled in her tongue,
And newhatcht hate makes every jest a wrong.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: look ye Mistress now I hit ye.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Why aye, you never use to miss a blot,
Especially when it stands so fair to hit.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: How mean ye mistress Barnes?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: That Mistress Gourse is in the hitting vain,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: I hot your man.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Aye, aye, my man, my man, but had I known,
I would have had my man stood nearer home,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Why had ye kept your man in his right place,
I should not then have hit him with an ace.

sp.speaker: Mis, Bar,
sp.l: Right by the Lord, a plague upon the bones.

sp.speaker: Mis, Gou,
sp.l: And a hot mischief on the curser too.

sp.speaker: M, Bar,
sp.l: How now wife?

sp.speaker: M, Gou,
sp.l: Why what is the matter woman?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Is is no matter. I am.

sp.speaker: Mis, Bar,
sp.l: Aye, you are.

sp.speaker: Mis, Gou,
sp.l: What am I?

sp.speaker: Mis, Bar,
sp.l: Why that is as you will be ever.

sp.speaker: Mis, Gou,
sp.l: That is every day as good as Barneses wife.

sp.speaker: Mis, Bar,
sp.l: And better too, then what needs all this trouble?
A single horse is worse than that bears double.

sp.speaker: M, Bar,
sp.l: Wife go to, have regard to what you say,
Let not your words pass forth the verge of reason:
But keep within the bounds of modesty,
For ill report doth like a Bailiff stand,
To pound the straying, and the wit lost tongue,
And makes it forfeit into follies hands.
Well wife, you know it is no honest part,
To entertain such guests with jests and wrongs,
What will the neighbouring country vulgar say,
When as they hear that you fell out at dinner?
Forsooth they will call it a pot quarrel straight,
The best they will name it, is a woman's jangling;
Go to, be ruled, be ruled.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Gods Lords, be ruled, be ruled
What, think ye I have such a babies wit,
To have a rods correction for my tongue?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I have some business in the town by three.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Till then let us walk into the Orchard sir.
What can you play at Tables?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Yes, I can.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: What, shall we have a game?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: And if you please.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Ifaith content, we will spend an hour so:
Sirrah fetch the Tables.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Sirrah Franke, whilst they are playing here,
We will to the green to Bowls.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Phillip content, Comes come hither sirrah,
When our Fathers part, call us upon the Green.
Philip come, a rubbers and so leave.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Come on.

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.p:
'sblood, I do not like the humour of these Springals,
they will spend all their Fathers good at gaming:
But let them troll the Bowls upon the Green,
I will troll the bowls in the Buttery, by the leave of
God and master Barnes: if his men be good fellows,
so it is, if they be not, let them go sneak up.
Enter Nicholas with the Tables. Exit.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: So set them down,
Mistress Goursey, how do you like this game?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Can ye, play at it?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: A little sir.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Faith so can my wife.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Why then master Barnes, and if you please,
Our wives shall try the quarrel twixt us two,
And we will look on.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I am content, what women will you play?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: I care not greatly.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Nor I, but that I think she will play me false.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I will see she shall not.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Nay sir, she will be sure you shall not see.
You of all men shall not mark her hand,
She hath such close conveyance in her play.

sp.speaker: M. Gor.
sp.l: Is she so cunning grown, come, come, let us see.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Yea mistress Barns, will ye not house your jests,
But let them room abroad so carelessly?
Faith, if your jealous tongue utter another,
I will cross ye with a jest, if ye, were my mother,
Come shall we play?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Aye, what shall we play a game?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: A pound a game.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: How wife?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Faith husband, not a farthing less.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: It is too much, a shilling were good game.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: No, we will be ill housewives once,
You have been oft ill husbands, let us alone.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Wife, will you play so much?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: I would be loath to be so frank a gamester
As mistress Goursey is, and yet for once
I will play a pound a game as well as she.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Go to, you will have your will.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Come, there is my stake.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: And there is mine.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Throw for the Dice: Ill luck then they are yours

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Master Goursey, who says that gaming is bad,
When such good Angels walk twixt every cast?

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: This is not noble sport, but royal play.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: It must be so, where royals walk so fast.

sp.speaker: Mist. Bar.
sp.l: Play right I pray.

sp.speaker: Mist. Gour.
sp.l: Why so I do.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Where stands your man?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: In his right place.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Good faith, I think, ye play me foul an ace.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: No wife, she plays ye true.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ba.
sp.l: Peace husband, peace, I will not be judged by you,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Husband, master Barnes, pray both go walk.
We cannot play, if standers by do talk.
School infancy, I am of age to speak,
And I know when to speak, shall I be chid for such a?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: What a? nay Mistress speak it out,
I scorn your stopped compares, compare not me
To any but your equals, mistress Barnes,

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Peace wife be quiet.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O persuade, persuade,
Wife, mistress Goursey, shall I win your thoughts
To composition of some kind effects?
Wife, if you love your credit leave this strife,
And come shake hands, with mistress Goursey here,

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Shall I shake hands? let her go shake her heels,
She gets nor hands, nor friendship at my hands,
And so sir while I live I will take heed,
What guests I bid again unto my house.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l:
Impatient woman, will you be so stiff in this
absurdness?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: I am impatient now I speak,
But sir I will tell you more another time,
Go to, I will not take it as I have done.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Nay, she might stay I will not long be here,
to trouble her: well master Barnes,
I am sorry that it was our haps today,
to have our pleasures parted with this fray,
I am sorry too for all that is amiss,
Especially that you are moved in this,
But be not so, it is but a woman's jar,
Their tongues are weapons, words their blows of war,
It was but a while we buffeted you saw,
And each of us was willing to withdraw,
There was no harm nor bloodshed you did see:
Tush, fear us not, for we shall well agree.
I take my leave sir, come kindharted man,
That speaks his wife so fair, aye now and then,
I know you would not for an hundredth pound,
That I should hear your voices churlish sound.
I know you have a far more milder tune
Than peace, be quiet wife, but I have done:
Will ye go home? the door directs the way,
But if you will not, my duty is to stay.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, why here is a right woman, is there not?
They both have dined, yet see what stomachs they have.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Well master Barnes, we cannot do with all,
Let us be friends still.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O master Goursey, the metal of our minds,
Having the temper of true reason in them,
Afford a better edge of argument.
For the maintain of our familiar loves,
Than the soft leaden wit of woman can,
Wherefore with all the parts of neighbour love,
I impart myself to master Goursey.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: And with exchange of love I do receive it,
Then here we will part partners of two cursed wives.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O where shall we find a man so blessed that is not,
But come, your business and my home affairs,
Makes me deliver that unfriendly word amongst friends, farewell.

sp.speaker: M. Gou,
sp.l: Twenty farewells sir.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: But hark ye master Goursey,
look ye persuade at home as I will do,
What man, we must not always have them foes.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: If I can help it.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: God help, God help,
Women are even untoward creatures still.
sp.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Philip Francis and his boy from bowling.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Come on franke Goursey, you have had good
luck to win the game.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Why tell me, is it not good, that never played before
upon your green.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
It is good, but that it cost me ten good crowns
that makes it worse.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Let it not grieve thee man, come over to us,
We will devise some game to make you win
Your money back again sweet Philip .
And that shall be ere long and if I live,
sp.p:
But tell me Francis, what good horses have ye to hunt
this Summer?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Two or three Jades or so.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Be they but Jades?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No faith my wag string here
Did founder one the last time that he rid,
The best gray Nag that ever I laid my leg over.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You mean the fleabitten.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good sir the same.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And was the same the best that ever you rid on?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Aye was it sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ifaith it was not sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, where had I one so good?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: One of my colour, and a better too.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
One of your colour, I never remember him one
of that colour.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Or of that complexion,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What is that ye call complexion in a horse.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The colour sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Set me a colour on your jest, or I will:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nay good sir hold your hands.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What. shall we have it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why sir I cannot paint.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Well then, I can
and I shall find a pencil for ye, sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Then I must find the table if you do.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A whoreson barren wicked urchin.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
look how you chase, you would be angry more
if I should tell it you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Go to, I will anger ye and if you do not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why sir, the horse that I do mean,
Hath a leg both straight and clean,
That hath nor spavin splint nor flaw.
But is the best that ever ye saw,
A pretty rising knee O knee,
It is as round as round may be,
The full flank makes the buttock round,
This palfrey standeth on no ground,
When as my master is on her back,
If that he once do say but, tic:
And if he prick her, you shall see
Her gallop amain, she is so free,
And if he give her but a nod,
She thinks it is a riding rod:
And if he will have her softly go,
Then she trips it like a Doe,
She comes so easy with the rain,
A twine thread turns her back again,
And truly I did never see yet,
A horse play proudly on the bit,
My master with good managing,
brought her first unto the ring,
He likewise taught her to curvet,
to run and suddenly to set,
She is cunning in the wild goose race,
Nay She is apt to every pace,
And to prove her colour good,
A flea enamoured of her blood,
Digged for canals in her neck,
And there made many a crimson speck,
I think there is none that use to ride,
But can her pleasant trot abide,
She goes so even upon the way,
She will not stumble in a day,
And when my master.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What do I?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nay nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O Fie Fanke fie,
Nay, nay, your reason hath no justice now,
I must needs say, persuade him first to speak,
Then chide him for it, tell me pretty wag,
Where stands this prancer, in what Inn or stable?
Or hath thy master put her out to run,
Then in what field, what champion seeds this courser?
This well paste bonnie steed that thou so praisest.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Faith sir I think.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: Villain, what do ye think?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I think that you sir have been asked by many,
But yet I never heard that ye told any,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well boy, then I will add one more to many,
And ask thy master where this Jennet feeds:
Come Franke tell me, nay prithee tell me Franke,
My good horse master tell me, by this light
I will not steal her from thee: if I do,
Let me be held a felon to thy love.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No Phillip no.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What, wilt thou were a point but with one tag?
Well Francis well, I see you are a wag.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p:
'Swounds where be these timber turners, these troll
the bowls, these green men, these.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What what sir?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: These bowlers sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well sir, what say you to bowlers?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Why I say they cannot be saved.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Your reason sir?

sp.speaker: Com
sp.l: Because they throw away their souls at every mark

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Their souls, how mean ye?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sirrah, he means the soul of the bowl.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Lord how his wit holds bias like a bowl.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Well, which is the bias?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This next to you.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Nay turn it this way, then the bowl goes true.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Rub, rub,

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Why rub?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why you overcast the mark and miss the way.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Nay boy I use to take the fairest of my play.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dicke Comes methinks thou art very pleasant,
When gottest thou this merry humour?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: In your fathers Seller, the merriest place in thehouse

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then you have been carousing hard,

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l:
Yes faith, it is our custom when your fathers men and
we meet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou art very welcome thither Dicke.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p:
By God I thank ye sir, I thank ye sir, by God I
have a quart of wine for ye sir in any place of the world,
there shall not a serving-man in Barkeshire fight better for
ye than I will do, if you have any quarrel in hand you
shall have the maiden-head of my new sword: I paid a
quarters wages for it by Iesus.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: O this meat-failer Dicke,
How well it has made the apparel of his wit,
And brought it into fashion of an honour,
Prithee Dicke Comes but tell me how thou dost?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Faith sir like a poor man of service.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Or serving-man.

sp.speaker: Comes,
sp.l: Indeed so called by the vulgar.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Why where the devil hadst thou that word?

sp.speaker: Comes,
sp.p:
O sir, you have the most eloquent ale in the
world, our blunt soil affords none such.

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.p: Philip leave talking with this drunken fool,
sp.l: Say sirrah where is my father?

sp.speaker: Comes,
sp.p:
Marry I thank ye for my very good cheer, O
Lord it is not so much worth, you see I am bold with ye,
Indeed you are not so bold as welcome, I pray ye come
oftener, Truly I shall trouble ye, all these ceremonies are
dispatched between them, and they are gone.

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.l: Are they so?

sp.speaker: Comes,
sp.l: Aye before God are they,

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.l: And wherefore came not you to call me then?

sp.speaker: Com,
sp.l: Because I was loath to change my game.

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.l: What game?

sp.speaker: Co,
sp.l: You were at one sort of bowls, as I was at another,

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Sirrah he means the buttery bowls of beer.

sp.speaker: Com,
sp.l: By god sir we tickled it.

sp.speaker: Fran,
sp.l: Why what a swearing keeps this drunken ass,
Canst thou not say but swear at every word?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Peace do not mar his humour prithee Franke.

sp.speaker: Com,
sp.p:
Let him alone, he is a springall, he knows not what
belongs to an oath.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sirrah, be quiet, or I do protest,

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Come, come, what do you protest?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: By heaven to crack your crown.

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: to crack my crown, I lay ye a crown of that,
Lay it down if ye dare:
Nay 'sblood, I will venture a quarters wages of that,
Crack my crown quoth he?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will ye not yet be quiet, will ye, urge me?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Urge ye with a pox, who urges ye?
You might have said so much to a clown,
Or one that had not been over the sea to see fashions,
I have I tell ye true, and I know who belongs to a man,
Crack my crown if ye can.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: If I can ye rascal.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold hair brain hold,
Dost thou not see he is drunk?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Nay let him come,
Though he be my masters son, I am my masters man,
And a man is a man in any ground of England:
Come, if he dares, he comes upon his death,
I will not budge an inch: no 'sblood will I not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Will ye not?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stay prithee Franke, Comes dost thou hear?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Here me no hears,
Stand away, I will trust none of you all,
If I have my back against a Cart wheel,
I would not care, if the devil came,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why ye fool, I am your friend.

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Fool on your face, I have a wife.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She is a whore then.

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: She is as honest as Nan Lawson.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What is she?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: One of his whores.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why hath he so many?

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Aye as many as there be Churches in London.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why that is a hundred and nine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Faith he lies a hundred.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then thou art a witness to nine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No by God, I will be witness to none:

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Now do I stand like the George at Colbrooke.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No thou standest like the Bull at Saint Albones.

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: Boy ye lie the horns.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The Bull is bitten, see how he buts.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Comes, comes, put up, my friend and thou art friends.

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: I will hear him say so first.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Franke prithee do, be friends and tell him so.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Go to, I am.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Put up sir, if ye be a man put up.

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.l: I am easily persuaded boy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ah ye mad slave.

sp.speaker: Comes.
sp.p:
Come, come, a couple of whoremasters I found
ye, and so I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lo Franke dost thou not see he is drunk,
That twits me with thy disposition?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What disposition?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nan Lawson, Nan Lawson.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Go to ye wag, it is well,
If ever ye get a wife, Ifaith I will tell,
Sirrah at home we have a Serving-man,
He is not humoured bluntly as Comes is,
Yet his condition makes me often merry,
I will tell thee sirrah, he is a fine neat fellow,
A spruce slave, I warrant ye, he will have,
His Cruel garters cross about the knee,
His woollen hose, as white as the driven snow,
His shoes dry Leather neat, and tied with red ribbons,
A Nosegay bound with laces in his Hat,
Bridelaces sir his hat, and all green hat.
Green coverlet, for such a grass green wit,
The Goose that grazeth on the green, quoth he,
May I eat on, when you shall buried be,
All Proverbs is his speech, he is Proverbs all.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why speaks he Proverbs?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Because he would speak truth,
And proverbs you will confess, are old said sooth.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I like this well, and one day I will see him,
But shall we part?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not yet, I will bring ye somewhat on your way,
And as we go, between your boy and you,
I will know where that brave Prancer stands at livery.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come, come, you shall not.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.l: Ifaith I will.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Wife in my mind, today you were to blame,
Although my patience did not blame ye for it:
Methought the rules of love and neighbourhood,
Did not direct your thoughts, all indirect
Were your proceedings, in the entertain
Of them that I invited to my house.
Nay stay, I do not chide but counsel wife,
And in the mildest manner that I may.
You need not view me with a servants eye,
Whose vassals senses tremble at the look
Of his displeased master, O my wife,
You are myself, when self sees fault in self.
Self is sin obstinate, if self amend not,
Indeed I saw a fault in thee myself,
And it hath set a foil upon thy fame,
Not as the foil doth grace the Diamond.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: What fault sir did you see in me today?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O do not set the organ of thy voice,
On such a grunting key of discontent:
Do not deform the beauty of thy tongue,
With such misshapen answers, rough wrathful words
Are bastards got by rashness in the thoughts,
Fair demeanours, are Virtues nuptial babes,
The offspring, of the well instructed soul,
O let them call thee mother, then my wife,
So seem not barren of good courtesy.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: So, have ye done?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Aye, and I had done well,
If you would do, what I advise for well.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.p:
Which is, that you would be good friends with
mistress Goursey.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: With mistress Goursey.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Aye sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Not so sweet husband.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Could you but show me any grounded cause.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: The grounded cause, I ground because I will not

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Your will hath little reason then I think.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Yes sir, my reason equalleth my will.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Let us hear your reason, for your will is great.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Why for I will not.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Is all your reason, for I will not wife,
Now by my soul I held ye for more wise,
Discreet, and of more temperature in sense,
Than in a sullen humour to affect,
That women's will borne common scholar phrase,
Oft have I heard a timely married girl,
That newly left to call her mother mam,
Her father Dad, but yesterday come from,
That is my good girl, God send thee a good husband,
And now being taught to speak the name of husband,
Will when she would be wanton in her will,
If her husband asked her why, say for I will,
Have I chid men for unmanly choice?
That would not fit their years, have I seen thee
Pupil such green young things, and with thy counsel
Tutor their wits, and art thou now infected,
With this disease of imperfection,
I blush for thee, ashamed at thy shame.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: A shame on her, that makes thee rate me so.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O blackmouthed rage, thy breath is boisterous,
And thou makest virtue shake at this high storm.
She is of good report, I know thou knowest it.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: She is not, nor I know not, but I know
That thou dost love her, therefore thinkst her so,
Thou bearst with her, because she bears with thee:
Thou mayst be ashamed to stand in her defence,
She is a strumpet, and thou art no honest man
To stand in her defence against thy wife:
If I catch her in my walk now by cocks bones,
I will scratch out both her eyes.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O God!

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Nay never say O God for the matter,
Thou art the cause, thou badest her to my house,
Only to blear the eyes of Goursie, didst not?
But I will send him word I warrant thee,
And ere I sleep too, trust upon it sir.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Methinks this is a mighty fault in her,
I could be angry with her: O if I be so,
I shall but put a Link unto a Torch,
And so give greater light to see her fault:
I will rather smother it in melancholy,
Nay, wisdom bids me shun that passion.
Then I will study for a remedy,
I have a daughter, now heaven invocate,
She be not of like spirit as her mother,
If so, she will be a plague unto her husband,
If that he be not patient and discreet,
For that I hold the ease of all such trouble,
Well, well, I would my daughter had a husband,
For I would see how she would demean herself
In that estate, it may be ill enough,
And so God shall help me, well remembered now,
Franke Goursey is his fathers son and heir,
A youth that in my heart I have good hope on,
My senses say a match, my soul applauds
The motion: O but his lands are great,
He will look high, why I will strain myself.
to make her dowry equal with his land,
Good faith if it were a match, it would be a means
To make their mothers friends: I will call my daughter,
to see how she is disposed to marriage:
Mall, where are ye?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Father, here I am.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Where is your mother?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: I saw her not forsooth, since you and she
Went walking both together to the garden.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Dost thou hear me girl? I must dispute with thee,

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Father, the question then must not be hard,
for I am very weak in argument.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Well, this it is, I say it is good to marry.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: And this say I, it is not good to marry.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Were it not good, then all men would not marry,
But now they do.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Marry not all, but it is good to marry.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Is it both good and bad, how can this be?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Why it is good to them that marry well,
To them that marry ill, no greater hell.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: If thou mightst marry well, wouldst thou agree?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: I cannot tell, heaven must appoint for me.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Wench I am studying for thy good indeed,

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: My hopes and duty, wish your thoughts good speed.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: But tell me wench, hast thou a mind to marry:

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: This question is too hard for bashfulness,
And Father, now ye pose my modesty,
I am a maid, and when ye ask me thus,
I like a maid must blush, look pale and wan,
And then look pale again, for we change colour,
As our thoughts change, with truefac'te passion
Of modest maidenhead, I could adorn me,
And to your question, make a sober curtsy,
And with close clipped civility be silent,
Or else say no forsooth, or I forsooth,
If I said no forsooth, I lie forsooth.
to lie upon myself were deadly sin,
Therefore I will speak truth and shame the devil.
Father, when first I heard ye name a husband,
At that same very name, my spirits quickened,
Despair before had killed them, they were dead,
Because it was my hap so long to tarry,
I was persuaded I should never marry.
And sitting sowing thus upon the ground,
I fell in trance of meditation,
But coming to myself, O Lord said I,
Shall it be so, must I unmarried die?
And being angry Father, farther said,
Now by saint Anne, I will not die a maid,
Good faith, before I came to this ripe groath,
I did accuse the labouring time of sloth,
Methought the year did run but slow about,
for I thought each year ten I was without,
Being fourteen, and toward the the other year:
Good Lord thought I, fifteen will never be here,
for I have heard my mother say, that then
Pretty maids, were fit for handsome men,
Fifteen past, sixeteen, and seventeen too,
What, thought I, will not this husband do?
Will no man marry me, have men forsworn,
Such beauty and such youth? shall youth be worn
As rich men's gowns, more with age than use?
Why then I let restrained fancy loose,
And bad it gaze for pleasure: then love swore me
To do whatever? my mother did before me,
Yet in good faith, I have been very loath,
But now it lies in you to save my oath:
If I shall have a husband, get him quickly,
for maids that wear Cork shoes, may step awry.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Believe me wench, I do not apprehend thee,
But for this pleasant answer do commend thee:
I must confess, love doth thee mighty wrong,
But I will see thee have thy right ere long,
I know a young may, whom I hold most fit,
to have thee, both for living and for wit,
I will go write about it presently.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Good father do, O God methinks I should
Wife it as fine as any woman could:
I could carry a port to be obeyed,
Carry a mastering eye upon my maid,
With minion do your business or I will make ye
And to all house authority betake me.
O God would I were married, by my troth,
But if I be not, I swear I will keep my oath.
How now minion, where have you been gadding?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Forsooth my father called me forth to him.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Your father, and what said he to ye I pray?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Nothing forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Nothing: that cannot be, something he said,

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Aye something, that as good as nothing was.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Come let me hear, that something nothing then.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Nothing but of a husband for me mother.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: A husband, that was something, but what husband?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Nay faith I know not mother, would I did.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: I would ye did, Ifaith are ye so hasty?

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Hasty mother, why how old am I?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Too young to marry.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Nay by the mass ye lie.
Mother, how old were you when you did marry?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: How old soere I was, yet you shall tarry.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Then the worse for me, hark Mother hark,
The Priest forgets that ere he was a Clarke,
When you were at my years, I will hold my life,
Your mind was to change maidenhead for wife.
Pardon me mother, I am of your mind,
And by my troth I take it but by kind.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Do ye hear daughter, you shall staye my leisure.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Do you hear mother, would you stay from pleasure,
When ye have mind to it? go to there is no wrong
Like this, to let maids lie alone so long,
Lying alone they muse but in their beds,
How they might loose their long kept maiden heads,
This is the cause there is so many scapes,
for women that are wise, will not lead Apes
In hell, I tell ye mother I say true,
Therefore come husband, maiden head adieu.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Well lusty guts, I mean to make ye stay,
And set some rubs in your minds smoothest nay.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: How now sirrah, where have ye been walking?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Over the meadows half way to Milton mother,
to bear my friend Franke Goursey company.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Where is your blue coat, your sword and buckler sir?
Get you suchlike habit for a serving-man,
If you will weight upon the brat of Goursey.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother, that you are moved this makes me wonder,
when I departed I did leave ye friends,
What undigested jar hath since betided?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Such as almost doth choke thy mother boy,
And stifles her with the conceit of it,
I am abused my son by Gourseys wife.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Mistress flirt, you foul strumpet,
Light of love, short heels, mistress Goursey,
Call her again and thou wert better no.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O my dear mother have some patience,

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Aye sir have patience, and see your father
to rifle up the treasure of my love,
And play the spendthrift upon such an harlot?
This fame will make me have patience, will it not?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This fame is women's most impatience,
Yet mother I have often heard ye say,
That you have found my father temperate,
And ever free from such affections.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Aye, till my too much love did glut his thoughts,
And make him seek for change.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O change your mind,
My father bears more cordial love to you.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Thou liest, thou liest, for he loves Gourseys wife, not me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now I swear mother you are much to blame,
I durst be sworn he loves you as his soul.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Wilt thou be pampered by affection?
Will nature teach thee such vild perjury?
Wilt thou be sworn, I forlorn, careless boy?
And if thou swearest, I say he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He loves ye but too well I swear,
Unless ye knew much better how to use him.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Doth he so sir? thou unnatural boy,
Too well sayst thou, that word shall cost thee somewhat,
O monstrous, have I brought thee up to this?
Too well: O unkind, wicked and degenerate,
Hast thou the heart to say so of thy mother?
Well, God will plague thee for it, I warrant thee,
Out on thee villain, fie upon thee wretch,
Out of my sight, out of my sight I say.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This air is pleasant, and doth please me well,
And here I will stay.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Wilt thou stubborn villain?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: How now, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Thou settest thy son to scoff and mock at me,
Is it not sufficient I am wronged of thee?
But he must be an agent to abuse me,
Must I be subject to my cradle too? O God, O God amend it.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Why how now Phillip, is this true my son?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dear father she is much impatient:
Never let that hand assist me in my need,
If I more said, than that she thought amiss,
To think that you were so licentious given,
And thus much more, when she inferred it more,
I swore an oath you loved her but too well,
In that as guilty I do hold myself,
Now that I come to more considerate trial,
I know my fault, I should have borne with her,
Blame me for rashness, then not for want of duty.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I do absolve thee, and come hither Philip,
I have writ a letter unto master Goursey,
And I will tell thee the contents thereof,
But tell me first, thinkst thou Franke Goursey loves thee?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If that a man devoted to a man,
Loyal, religious, in loves hallowed vows,
If that a man that is soul laboursome,
To work his own thoughts to his friends delight,
May purchase good opinion with his friend,
Then I may say, I have done this so well,
That I may think Franke Goursey loves me well

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: It is well, and I am much deceived in him,
And if he be not sober, wise, and valiant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I hope my father takes me for thus wise,
I will not glue myself in love to one
That hath not some desert of virtue in him,
Whatever you think of him, believe me father,
He will be answerable to your thoughts,
In any quality commendable.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Thou cheerest my hopes in him, and in good faith,
Thou hast made my love complete unto thy friend,
Philip I love him, and I love him so,
I could afford him a good wife I know.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father, a wife?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Phillip a wife.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I lay my life my sister.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Aye in good faith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then father he shall have her, he shall I swear.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: How canst thou say so, knowing not his mind?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: All is one for that, I will go to him straight,
Father if you would seek this seven years day,
You could not find a fitter match for her,
And he shall have her, I swear he shall,
He were as good be hanged as once deny her, Ifaith I will to him.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Hare-brain, hare-brain stay,
As yet we do not know his fathers mind,

Why what will master Goursey say
my son,
If we should motion it without his knowledge?
Go to, he is a wise and discreet Gentleman,
And that expects from me all honest parts,
Nor shall he fail his expectation,
First I do mean to make him privy to it,
Phillip this letter is to that effect.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father, for Gads sake send it quickly then,
I will call your man, what Hugh, where is Hugh, there ho,

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.p:
Phillip if this would prove a match, It were the
only means that could be found, To make thy mother friends
with Mis. Gou.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How a match? I will warrant ye a match.
My Sister is fair, Franke Goursie he is rich,
His dowry too will be sufficient,
Frank is young, and youth is apt to love,
And by my troth my sisters maidenhead
Stands like a game at tennis, if the ball
Hit into the hole or hazard, farewell all.
How now, where is Hugh?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why what doth this proverbial with us, why where is Hugh?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where is Hugh I say?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Be not so hasty Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father let me alone,
I do it but to make myself some sport,
This formal fool your man speaks naught but proverbs,
And speak men what they can to him, he will answer
With some rime, rotten sentence, or old saying,
Such spokes as the ancient of the parish use,
With neighbour it is an old proverb and a true,
Goose giblets are good meat, old sack better than new:
Then says another, neighbour that is true,
And when each man hath drunk his gallon round,
A penny pot, for that is the old man's gallon,
Then doth he lick his lips and stroke his beard,
That is glued together with his slavering drops
Of yeasty ale, and when he scarce can trim,
His gouty fingers, thus he will philip it,
And with a rotten hem say hey my hearts,
Merry go sorry cock and pie my hearts,
But then their saving penny proverb comes,
And that is this: they that will to the wine,
By our lady mistress shall lay their penny to mine,
This was one of this penny father's bastards,
for on my life he was never begot,
Without the consent of some great proverbmonger.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: O ye are a wag,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, now unto my business,
'swounds will that mouth that is made of old fed saws,
And nothing else, say nothing to us now?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
O master Philip forbear, you must not leap over
the style before you come at it, haste makes waste, soft fire
makes sweet malt, not too fast for falling, there is no haste to
hang true men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Father we have it, ye see we have it, now will I see if my
memory will serve, for some proverbs too. O a painted cloth
were as well worth a shilling, as a thief worth a halter: well,
after my hearty commendations as I was at the making hereof,
so it is, that I hope as you speed, so you are sure a swift horse
will tier, but he that trots easily will endure, you have most
learnedly proverbed it, commending the virtue of patience or
forbearance, but yet you know forbearance is no quittance

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
I promise ye master Philip you have spoken as true
as steel.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Father, there is a proverb well applied.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
And it seemeth unto me, aye it seems to me, that you
master Phillip mock me, do you not know qui mocat mocabitur,
mock age and see how it will prosper?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why ye whoreson proverb book bound up in folio,
have ye no other sense to answer me,
But every word a proverb, no other English?
Well, I will fulfil a proverb on thee straight.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: What is it sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will fetch my fist from thine ear.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Bear witness he threatens me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father that same is the cowards common proverb,
But come, come sirrah, tell me where Hugh is?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
I may and I will, I need not except I list, you shall
not command me, you give me neither meat, drink, nor
wages, I am your fathers man, and a man is a man if he have but a
hose on his head, do not misuse me so, do not, for though he that
is bound must obey, yet he that will not tarry may run away
so he may.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Peace Nicke, I will see he shall use thee well,
Go to peace sirrah, here Nicke take this letter,
Carry it to him to whom it is directed.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: To whom is it?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Why read it, canst thou read?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Forsooth though none of the best, yet meanly:

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Why dost thou not use it?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
Forsooth as use makes perfectness, so seldom seen
is soon forgotten.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Well said, but go, it is to master Goursey,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now sir, what proverb have ye to deliver a letter?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
What need you to care? who speaks to you? you
may speak when ye are spoken to, and keep your wind to
cool your pottage: well well, you are my masters son and
you look for his land, but they that hope for dead men's
shoes, may hap go barefoot: take heed, as soon goes the
young sheep to the pot as the old. I pray God save my Masters
life, for seldom comes the better.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O he hath given it me: farewell proverbs.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Farewell frost.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: shall I fling an old shoe after ye?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: No, you should say God send fair weather after me,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I mean for good luck.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: A good luck on ye.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Alas poor fool, he uses all his wit,

l.emph: Phillip in faith this mirth hath cheered thought,

sp.l: And cozened it of aright play of passion,
Go after Nick, and when thou thinkst he is there,
Go in and urge to that which I have writ,
I willin these meadows make a circling walk,
And in my meditation conjure so,
As that some send of thought self-eating anger,
shall by my spells of treason vanish quite
Away, and let me hear from thee tonight

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tonight, yes that you shall, but hark ye father,
look that you my sister waking keep,
For Franke I swear shall kiss her ere I sleep.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: I am very dry with walking over the green,
Butler some beer, sirrah call the Butler.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nay faith sir, we must have some smith to give the butler
A drench, or cut him in the forehead, for he hath got
A horses disease, namely the staggers, tonight he is a good
Housewife, he reels all that he wrought today, and he were good
Now to play at dice, for he casts excellent well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How meanest thou, is he drunk?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but I am sure he hath more liquor in him
Than a whole dicker of hides, he is socked thoroughly Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well, go and call him, bid him bring me drink.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My mother pouts and will look merrily,
Neither upon my father nor on me,
He says she fell out with mistress Barnes today,
Then I am sure they will not be quickly friends,
Good Lord what kind of creatures women are?
Their love is lightly won and lightly lost,
And then their hate is deadly and extreme.
He that doth take a wife, betakes himself
To all the cares and troubles of the world.
Now her disquietness doth grieve my father,
Grieves me, and troubles all the house besides,
What, shall I have some drink? how now a horn?
Belike the drunken knave is fallen asleepe,
And now the boy doth wake him with his horn:
How now sirrah, where is the butler?

sp.p:
Marry sir, where he was even now asleepe, but I
waked him, and when he waked, he thought he was in master
Barnses buttery, for he stretched himself thus: and yawning
said, Nicke, honest Nicke fill a fresh bowl of ale, stand to it
Nicke if thou beest a man of Gods making, stand to it: and
then I winded my horn, and he is horn mad.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l:
Boy hey, ho boy, if thou beest a man draw, O here is
a blessed moonshine God be thanked, boy is not this goodly
weather for barley?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Spoken like a right maulster Hodge, but dost thou
hear? thou art not drunk.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: No, I scorn that In faith.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: But thy fellow Dicke Coomes is mightily drunk.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p:
Drunk, a plague on it, when a man cannot carry his
drink well: 'sblood I will stand to it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hold man see if thou canst stand first.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p:
Drunk: he is a beast if he be drunk, there is no man
that is a sober man will be drunk, he is a boy if he be drunk.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, he is a man as thou art.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
Thus it is when a man will not be ruled by his friends,
I bad him keep under the lee, but he kept down the weather,
two bows I told him be would be taken with a planet, but
the wisest of us all may fall

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: True Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
Whoopee lend me thy hand Dicke, I am fallen into a
well, lend me thy hand I shall be drowned else.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hold fast by the bucket Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: A rope on it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Aye there is a rope on it, but where art thou Hodge?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: In a Well, I prithee draw up.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come give up thy body, wind up, hoist.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: I am over head and ears,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: In all Hodge, in all.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How loathsome is this beast man's shape to me?
This mould of reason so unreasonable,
Sirrah, why dost thou trip him down seeing he is drunk?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Because sir I would have drunkards cheap.

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.l: How mean ye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Why they say that when anything hath a fall, it is cheap,
and so of drunkards.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Go to help him up, but hark who knocks?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Sir here is one of master Barnesies men with a letter to
my old master.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Which of them is it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: They call him Nicholas sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Go call him in.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: By your leave ho, how now young master, how is it?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: look ye sirrah where your fellow lies,
He is a fine taking is he not?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Whoopee Hodge, where art thou man, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: O in a Well.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: In a well man, nay then thou art deep in understanding.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Aye once today you were almost so sir.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p:
Who I, go to young master, I do not like this humour
in ye true, give every man his due, and give him no
more: say I was in such a case, go to, it is the greatest indignation
that can be offered to a man: and but a man is more godlier
given, you were able to make him: swear out his heart blood,
what though that honest Hodge have cut his finger here? or as
some say, cut a feather? what though he be mump, misled, blind,
or as it were, it is no consequent to me: you know I have drunk
all the Alehouses in Abington dry, and laid the taps on the
tables when I had done: 'sblood I will challenge all the true rob-pots
in Europe, to leap up to the chin in a barrel of Beer,
and if I cannot drink it down to my foot ere I leave, and then
set the tap in the midst of the house, and then turn a good turn
on the toe on it, let me be counted nobody, a pingler, nay let
me bound to drink nothing but small Beer seven years after,
and I had as leese be hanged.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Peace sir, I must speak with one, Nicholas I think
your name is.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: True as the skin between your brows.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well, how doth thy master?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Forsooth live, and the best doth no better.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Where is the letter he hath sent me?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l:
Ecce signum,
here it is.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is right as Philip said, it is a fine fool,
This letter is directed to my father,
I will carry it to him, Dick Coomes make him drink.

sp.speaker: Coomes
sp.l: Aye, I will make him drink if he will.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Not so Richard, it is good to be merry and wise.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Well Nicholas, as thou art Nicholas, welcome, but as
thou art Nicholas and a boon companion, ten times welcome,
Nicholas give me thy hand, shall we be merry? and we shall, say
but we shall, and let the first word stand.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Indeed, as long lives the merry man as the sad,
An ounce of debt will not pay a pound of care.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: Nay a pound of care, will not pay an ounce of debt.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Well, it is a good horse never stumbles, but who lies here?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
It is our Hodge, and I think he lies asleep, you made him
drunk at your house today, but I will pepper some of you for it.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Aye Richard, I know you will put a man over the shoes, and
if you can, but he is a fool will take more than will do him good.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: 'sblood ye shall take more than will do ye good,
Or I will make ye clap under the table.

sp.speaker: Nich.
Coomes.
sp.p:
Ha my resolved Nicke Froligozene, fill the pot
Hostess, 'swounds you whore, Harry Hooke is a rascal: help
me but carry my fellow Hodge in, and we will crush it Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By this I think, the letter is delivered,
And it will be shortly time that I step in,
And woo their favours for my sisters fortune,
And yet I need not, she may do as well,
But yet not better, as the case doth stand,
Between our mothers, it may make them friends,
Nay I would swear that she would do as well,
Were she a stranger to one quality,
But they are so acquainted, they will near part,
Why she will flout the devil and make blush,
The boldest face of man, that ever man saw.
He that hath best opinion of his wit,
And hath his brain pan fraught with bitter Jests,
Or of his own, or stolen, or howsoever,
Let him stand never so high in his own conceit,
Her wit is a sun, that melts him down like butter,
And makes him sit at table Pancakewise,
Flat flat, God knows, and never a word to say.
Yet She will not leave him then, but like a tyrant,
She will persecute the poor witbeaten man,
And so be bang him with dry bobs and scoffs,
When he is down, most coward-like good faith,
As I have pitied the poor patient.
There came a Farmers son awooing to her,
A proper man, well landed too he was,
A man that for his wit need not to ask,
What time of year it were good to sow his Oats,
Nor yet his Barley, no nor when to reap,
to plough his Fallows, or to fell his Trees,
Well experienced thus each kind of way,
After a two months labour at the most,
And yet it was well he held it out so long,
He left his love, she had so last his lips,
He could say nothing to her, but God be with ye.
Why she, when men have dined and call for cheese,
Will straight maintain, Jests bitter to digest,
And then some one will fall to argument,
Who if he ouermaister her with reason,
Then she will begin to buffet him with mocks.
Well I do doubt, Fraunces hath so much spleen,
They will" near agree, but I will moderate.
By this time, it is time I think to enter,
This is the house, shall I knock? no I will not
Wait while one comes out to answer:
I will in, and let them be as bold with us:

div2.stage: Enter maister Goursey reading a letter.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: If that they like, her dowry shall be equal
To your son's wealth or possibility,
It is a means to make our wives good friends,
And to continue friendship twixt us two.
It is so indeed, I like this motion,
sp.p:
And it hath my consent, because my wife, is sore infected and
hartsick with hate: and I have sought the Galen of advice, which
only tells me this same potion, to be most sovereign for her
sickness cure.
sp.l: Here comes my son, conferring with his friend.
Fraunces, how do you like your friends discourse?
I know he is persuading to this motion.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Father, as matter that befits a friend,
But yet not me, that am too young to marry.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.p:
Nay, if thy mind be forward with thy years,
Thy time is lost thou tarriest, trust me boy, This match is answerable
to thy birth, Her blood and portion, give each other grace:
These indented lines promise a sum, And I do like the value,
If it hap Thy liking to accord to my consent,
It is a match: wilt thou go see the maid?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Never trust me Father, the shape of marriage,
Which I do see in others, seem so severe,
I dare not put my youngling liberty,
Under the awe of that instruction,
And yet I grant the limits of free youth
Going astray, are often restrained by that:
But mistress wedlock, to my scholar thoughts,
Will be too cursed I fear, O should she snip
My pleasureayming mind, I shall be sad,
And swear, when I did marry I was mad.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: But boy, let my experience teach thee this,
Yet in good faith, thou speakest not much amiss,
When first thy mothers fame to me did come,
Thy Grandsire thus, then came to me his son:
And even my words to thee, to me he said,
And as to me thou sayst, to him I said,
But in a greater huff, and hotter blood,
I tell ye on youths tiptoes then I stood,
Says he (good-faith this was his very say)
When I was young, I was but reasons fool,
And went to wedding, as to wisdoms school:
It taught me much, and much I did forget,
But beaten much by it, I got some wit,
Though I was shackled from an often scout,
Yet I would wanton it when I was out,
It was comfort, old acquaintance then to meet,
Restrained liberty, attained is sweet,
Thus said my father to thy father, son
And thou mayst do this too, as I have done.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Infaith good counsel Franke, what sayst thou to it?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Phillip, what should I say?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why, either aye or no.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O but which rather?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why that which was persuaded by thy father.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That is aye, then aye, O should it fall out ill,
Then I, for I am guilty of that ill.
I will not be guilty, no.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What backward gone?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Phillip, no whit backward, that is on.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O staye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tush, there is no good luck in this delay,
Come, come, late comers man are shent.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Heigh ho, I fear I shall repent,
Well, which way Franke?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why this way.
Canst thou tell,
And takest upon thee to be my guide to hell,
But which way father?

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: That way.

sp.speaker: Franke.
sp.l: Aye, you know,
You found the way to sorrow long ago,
Father God boy ye, you have sent your son,
to seek on earth an earthly day of doom,
Where I shall be adjudged alack the ruth,
To penance for the follies of my youth.
Well I must go, but by my troth my mind,
Is not love capable to that kind,
O I have looked upon this mould of men,
As I have done upon a Lion's den,
Praised I have the gallant beast I saw,
Yet wished me no acquaintance with his paw,
And must I now be grated with them well,
Yet I may hap to prove a Daniell,
And if I do, sure it would make me laugh,
to be among wild beasts and yet be safe,
Is there a remedy to abate their rage,
Yes many catch them, and put them in a cage,
Aye but how catch them, marry in your hand,
Carry me forth a burning fire brand,
For with his sparkling shine, old rumour says,
A fire brand the swiftest runner frays,
This I may do, but if it prove not so,
Then man goes out to seek his adjunct woe,
Phillip away, and Father now adieu,
In quest of sorrow I am sent by you.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Return the messenger of joy my son,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Seldom in this world, such a work is done.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nay, nay, make haste, it will be quickly night.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why is it not good to woo by candle light.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But if we make not haste they will be abed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: The better Candles out, and Curtains spread.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I know, though that my son's years be not many,
Yet he hath wit to woo as well as any,
Here comes my wife, I am glad my boy is gone
Ere she came hither, how now wife, how is it?
What are ye yet in charity and love with mistress Barnes?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: With mistress Barnes, why master Barnes I pray,

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Because she is your neighbour and

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: And what?
And a jealous slandering spiteful quean she is,
One that would blur my reputation,
With her opprobrious malice if she could,
She wrongs her husband, to abuse my fame,
it is known that I have lived in honest name,
All my lifetime, and been your right true wife.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I entertain no other thought my wife,
And my opinion is sound of your behaviour.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: And my behaviour is as sound as it.
But her ill speeches seeks to rot my credit,
And eat it with the worm of hate and malice.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Why then preserve it you by patience.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: By patience, would ye have me shame myself,
And cozen myself to bear her injuries:
Not while her eyes be open will I yield,
A word, a letter, a syllables value,
But equal and make even her wrongs to me,
To her again.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Then in good faith wife ye are more to blame.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Am I to blame sir, pray what letter is this?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: There is a dearth of manners in ye wife,
Rudely to snatch it from me, give it me?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: You shall not have it sir, till I have read it.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Give it then, and I will read it to you.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: No, no, it shall not need, I am a scholar
Good enough to read a letter sir.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Gods passion, if she knew but the contents,
She will seek to cross this match, she shall not read it.
Wife, give it me, come, come, give it me.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Husband, in very deed you shall not have it.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: What will you move me to impatience then?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Tut, tell not me of your impatience,
But since you talk sir of impatience,
You shall not have the letter by this light,
Till I have read it, soul I will burn it first.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Go to, ye move me wife, give me the letter,
In troth I shall grow angry, if you do not,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Grow to the house top with your anger sir.
Near tell me, I care not thus much for it.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Well, I can bear enough, but not too much,
Come give it me, it were best you be persuaded,
By God ye make me swear, now God forgive me.
Give me I say, and stand not long upon it,
Go to, I am angry at the heart, my very heart.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Heart me no hearts, you shall not have it sir,
No you shall not, near look so big,
I will not be afraid at your great looks,
You shall not have it, no you shall not have it.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Shall I not have it, in troth I will try that,
Minion I will have it, shall I not have it, I am loath,
Go to, take pausment, be advised,
Infaith I will, and stand not long upon it,
A woman of your years, I am ashamed,
A couple of so long continuance,
Should thus, Gods foot, I cry God heartily mercy,
Go to, ye vex me, and I will vex ye for it,
Before I leave ye I will make ye glad,
To tender it on your knees, hear ye I will I will,
What worse and worse, stomach true Ifaith,
Shall I be crossed by you in my old age?
And where I should have greatest comfort too,
A nurse of you, nurse in the devils name,
Go to mistress, by Gods precious dear,
If ye delay:

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Lord, Lord, why in what a fit,
Are you in husband, so enraged, so moved,
And for so slight a cause, to read a letter,
Did this letter love, contain my death,
Should you deny my sight of it, I would not,
Nor see my sorrow, nor eschew my danger,
But willingly yield me a patient,
unto the doom that your displeasure gave,
Here is the letter, not for that your incensement,
Makes me make offer of it, but your health,
Which anger I do fear hath crazed,
And viperlike hath sucked away the blood,
That wont was to be cheerful in this cheek,
How pale ye look.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Pale, can ye blame me for it, I tell you true,
An easy matter could not thus have moved me,
Well this resignment, and so forth, but woman
This fortnight shall I not forget ye for it.
Ha, ha, I see that roughness can do somewhat,
I did not think good faith, I could have set,
So sour a face upon it, and to her,
My bed embracer, my right bosom friend,
I would not that she should have seen the letter
As poor a man as I am by my troth,
for twenty pound: well I am glad I have it.
Ha, here is adoe about a thing of nothing,
What stomach, ha it is happy you are come down.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Well crafty Fox, I will hunt ye by my troth,
Deal ye so closely? well I see his drift,
He would not let me see the letter, least
That I should cross the match, and I will cross it:
Dick Coomes?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Come hither Dicke, thou art a man I love,
And one whom I have much in my regard.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: I thank ye for it mistress, I thank ye for it.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Nay here is my hand, I will do very much for thee,
If ever thou standest in need of me,
Thou shalt not lack, whilst thou hast a day to live.
Money, apparel,

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: And sword and Bucklers.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: And sword and Bucklers too my gallant Dick,
So thou wilt use but this in my defence.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
This, no faith I have no mind to this, break my
head if this break not if we come to any tough play, nay mistress
I had a sword, aye the flower of smithfield, for a sword, a right fox
Ifaith, with that if a man had come over with a smooth and
a sharpe stroke, it would have cried twang, and then when I
had doubled my point, traced my ground, and had carried my
buckler before me like a garden Butt, and then come in with a
crossblow, and over the pick of his buckler two ells long, it
would have cried twang, twang, metal, metal, but a dog
hath his day, it is gone, and there are few good ones made now,
I see by this dearth of good swords, and dearth of sword and
buckler fight, begins to grow out, I am sorry for it, I shall never
see good manhood again, if it be once gone, this poking
fight of rapier and dagger will come up then, then a man, a tall
man and a good sword and buckler man, will be spitted like a
cate or a cony, then a boy will be as good as a man, unless the
Lord show mercy unto us, well, I had as lief be hanged as
live to see that day, well mistress, what shall I do? what shall I
do?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Why this brave Dicke, thou knowest that Barnes wife
And I am foes, now man me to her house,
And though it be dark Dicke, yet we will have no light,
Least that thy master should prevent our journey
By seeing our depart: then when we come,
And if that she and I do fall to words,
Set in thy foot and quarrel with her men,
Draw, fight, strike, hurt, but do not kill the slaves,
And make as though thou strikest at a man,
And hit her if thou canst, a plague upon her,
She hath misused me Dicke, wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: Coomes,
sp.l: Yes mistress I will strike her men, but God forbid,
That ever Dicke Coomes should be seen to strike a woman.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.p:
Why she is mankind, therefore thou mayest strike
her.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Mankind, nay if she have any part of a man, I will
strike her I warrant.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: That is my good Dicke, that is my sweet Dicke,

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
'Swounds who would not be a man of valour to have
such words of a Gentlewoman, one of their words are more
to me than twenty of these russet coats cheesecakes, and buttermakers:
well, I thank God I am none of these cowards, well
if a man have any virtue in him, I see he shall be regarded.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.p:
Art thou resolved Dicke? wilt thou do this for
me, and if thou wilt, here is an earnest penny, of that rich
guerdon I do mean to give thee.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p:
An angel mistress let me see, stand you on my left
hand, and let the angel lie on my buckler on my right
hand, for fear of loosing, now here stand I to be tempted,
they say, every man hath two spirits attending on him, either
good or bad, now I say a man hath no other spirits but either
his wealth or his wife, now which is the better of them, why
that is as they are used, for use neither of them well, and they
are both naught, but this is a miracle to me, that gold that is
heavy hath the upper, and a woman that is light doth soonest
fall, considering that light things aspire, and heavy things
soonest go down, but leave these considerations to sir Iohn,
they become a black coat better than a blue, well mistress
I had no mind today to quarrel, but a woman is made to be
a man's seducer, you say quarrel.

sp.speaker: Mis Gou.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: There speaks an angel is it good?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Then I cannot do amiss, the good angel goes with
me.

div2.stage: Enter sir Raphe Smith his Lady and Will.

sp.speaker: Sir. Rap.
sp.l: Come on my hearts, Ifaith it is ill luck,
To hunt all day and not kill anything.
What sayst thou Lady, art thou weary yet?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I must not say so sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ra.
sp.l: Although thou art.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And can you blame her to be forth so long,
And see no better sport?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Good faith it was very hard.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: No it was not ill.
Because you know it is not good to kill.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes venison Lady.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: No indeed nor them,
Life is as dear in dear as it is in men.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: But they are killed for sport,

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: But that is bad play,
When they are made to sport their lives away.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: It is fine to see them run.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What out of breath?
They run but ill that run themselves to death,

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: They might make then less haste and keep their wind,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why then they see the hounds brings death behind.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Then it were as good for them at first to stay,
As to run long and run their lives away.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Aye but the stoutest of you all that is here,
Would run from death and nimbly scud for fear,
Now by my troth I pity those poor elves.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Well, they have made us but bad sport today,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yes it was my sport to see them scape away.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I wish that I had been at one bucks fall.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Out thou wood tyrant thou art worst of all.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: A woodman Lady, but no tyrant I:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yes tyrant-like thou lovest to see lives die.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Lady no more I do not like this luck,
To hunt all day and yet not kill a buck,
Well, it is late, but yet I swear I will
Stay here all night but I a buck will kill.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: All night, nay good sir Raph Smith do not so.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Content ye Lady, Will, go fetch my bow,
A berry of fair Rooes I saw today,
Down by the groves, and there I will take me stand,
And shoot at one, God send a lucky hand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will ye not then sir Raph go home with me?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: No, but my men shall bear thee company.
Sirs man her home, Will bid the huntsmen couple,
And bid them well reward their hounds tonight.
Lady farewell, Will haste ye with the bow,
I will stay for thee here by the grove below.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I will, but it will be dark I shall not see,
How shall I see ye then?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why hollow to me and I will answer thee.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Enough I will.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How willingly dost thou consent to go,
To fetch thy master that same killing bow.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Guilty of death I willing am in this,
Because it was our ill haps today to miss,
To hunt and not to kill is hunters sorrow,
Come Lady, we will have venison ere tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come Franke now are we hard by the house,
But how now, sad?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, to study how to woe thy sister,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How man, how to woe her? why no matter how,
I am sure thou wilt not be ashamed to woe,
Thy cheeks not subject to a childish blush,
Thou hast a better warrant by thy wit,
I know thy oratory can unfold,
Quick invention, plausible discourse,
And set such painted beauty on thy tongue,
As it shall ravish every maiden sense,
For Franke, thou art not like the russet youth
I told thee of, that went to woe a wench,
And being full stuffed up with fallow wit,
And meadow matter, asked the pretty maid,
How they sold corn last market day with them;
Saying: indeed it was very dear with them;
And do ye hear, he had not need be so,
for thee will Francis thoroughly try your wit,
Sirrah she will bow the metal of your wits,
And if they crack she will not hold ye currant,
Nay she will way your wit as men way angels,
And if it lack a grain, she will not change with ye,
I cannot speak it but in passion,
She is a wicked wench to make a jest,
Aye men how full of flouts and mocks she is?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Some Aqua vitae reason to recover
This sick discourser, swooned not prithee Phillip:
Tush, tush, I do not think her as thou sayst,
Perhaps she is opinions darling Phillip.
Wise in repute, the crows bird O my friend,
Some judgments slave themselves to small desert,
And wondernize the birth of common wit,
When their own strangeness do but make that strange,
And their ill errors do but make that good,
And why should men debase to make that good,
Perhaps such admiration wins her wit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, I am glad to hear this bold prepare,
For this encounter, forward hardy Frazke,
Yonder is the window, with the candle in it,
Belike she is putting on her night attire,
I told ye Franke it was late, well I will call her,
Marry softly that my mother may not hear:
Mall, sister Mall.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How now, who is there?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It is I.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: It is I, who I? I quoth the dog, or what?
A christ cross row I?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No sweet piccaninny.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O is it you wild oats?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye forsooth wanton.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well said scapethrift.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Phillip be these your usual best salutes?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is the harmless chiding of that dove,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Dove, one of those that draw the Queen of love?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How now? who is that brother, who is that with ye?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A Gentleman my friend.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: By our lady he hath a pure wit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How means your holy judgment?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O well put in sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Up you would say.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well climbed Gentleman,
I pray sir tell me, do you cart the queen of love?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not cart her, but couch her in your eye,
And a fit place for gentle love to lie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Aye but methinks you speak without the book,
To place a four wheel waggon in my look,
Where will you have room to have the coachman sit?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay that were but small manners, and not sit,
His duty is before you bare to stand,
Having a lusty whipstock in his hand.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The place is void, will you provide me one?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And if you please I will supply the room.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But are ye cunning in the carman's lash?
And can ye whistle well?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes I can well direct the coach of love.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ah cruel carter, would you whip a dove?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Hark ye sister?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay, but hark ye brother?
Whose white boy is that same? know ye his mother?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: he is a Gentleman of a good house,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Why is his house of gold, is it not made of lime and
stone like this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I mean he is well descended.
God be thanked.
Did he descend some steeple or some ladder?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, you will still be cross, I tell ye sister,
This Gentleman by all your friends consent,
Must be your husband.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay not all, some sing another note,
My mother will say no, I hold a groat,
But I thought it was somewhat, he would be a carter,
He hath been whipping lately some blind bear.
