And now he would firk the blind boy here with us.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, do you hear, you sister, mistress would have,
You that do long for somewhat, I know what.
My father told me, go to I will tell all,
If ye be cross, do ye hear me? I have laboured
A years work in this afternoon for ye,
Come from your cloister, votary, chase Nun,
Come down and kiss Franke Gourseis mothers son.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Kiss him I pray?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Go to stale maidenhead, come down I say,
You seventeen and upward, come come down,
You will stay till twenty else for your wedding gown,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nun, votary, stale maidenhead, seventeen and upward,
Here be names, what nothing else?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes, or a fair built steeple without bells.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Steeple good people, nay another cast.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Aye, or a well made ship without a mast.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Fie not so big, by one part of four.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why then ye are a boat without an oar.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O well rode wit, but what is your fare I pray?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Your fair self must be my fairest pay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay, if you be so dear, I will choose another.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why take your first man wench, and go no further.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Peace Francis, hark ye sister, this I say, You know my
mind, or answer aye or nay, Wit and judgment hath resolved
his mind, And he foresees what after he shall find,
sp.l: If such discretion then shall govern you,
Vow love to him, he will do the like to you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Vow love? who would not love such a comely feature?
Nor high nor low, but of the middle stature,
A middle man that is the best size indeed,
I like him well, Love grant us well to speed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And let me see a woman of that tallness,
So slender, and of such a middle smallness,
So old enough, and in each part so fit,
So fair, so kind, endued with so much wit,
Of so much wit as it is held a wonder,
It were pity to keep love and her asunder,
Therefore go up my joy, call down my bliss,
Bid her come seal the bargain with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Franke, Franke, I come through dangers; death and harms,
To make Loves patient with thy seal of arms.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But sister softly, least my mother hear.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hush then, mum, mouse in cheese, cat is near.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Now in good faith Phillip this makes me smile,
That I have wooed and won in so small while.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Francis, indeed my sister I dare say,
Was not determined to say thee nay,
For this same the other thing, called maidenhead,
Hangs by so small a hair or spiders thread,
And worn so too with time, it must needs fall,
And like a well lured hawk, she knows her call.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Whist brother whist, my mother heard me tread,
And asked who is there? I would not answer her,
She called a light, and up she is gone to seek me,
There when she finds me not, she will hither come,
Therefore dispatch let it be quickly done,
Francis, my loves lease I do let to thee,
Date of my life and thine, what sayst thou to me?
The entering, fine, or income thou must pay,
Are kisses and embraces every day,
And quarterly I must receive my rent,
You know my mind.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I guess at thy intent,
Thou shalt not miss a minute of thy time.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why then sweet Francis I am only thine,
Brother bear witness.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Do ye deliver this as your deed?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I do I do.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: God send ye both good speed, Gods Lord my mother:
Stand aside and closely too, least that you be espied.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother it is I.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: You disobedient ruffian, careless wretch,
That said your father loved me but too well,
I will think on it when thou thinkst I have forgot it:
Who is with thee else? how now minion you?
With whom? with him? why what makes you here sir?
And thus late too, what hath your mother sent ye
To cut my throat, that here you be in weight?
Come from him mistress, and let go his hand,
Will ye not sir?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Stay mistress Barnes, or mother, what ye will,
She is my wife, and here she shall be still.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: How sir your wife? wouldst thou my daughter have?
I will rather have her married to her grave,
Go to be gone, and quickly, or I swear,
I will have my men beat ye for staying here,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Beat him mother, as I am true man,
They were better beat the devil and his dam.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: What wilt thou take his part?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To do him good,
If it were to wade hitherto up in blood.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Godamercy Philip, but mother hear me.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Callest thou me mother, no thy mothers name
Carries about with it, reproach and shame:
Give me my daughter, ere that she shall wed,
A strumpets son, and have her so mislead,
I will marry her to a Carter: come I say,
Give me her from thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mother not today,
Nor yet tomorrow, till my lives last morrow,
Make me leave that, which I with leave did borrow,
Here I have borrowed love, I will not deny it,
Thy wedding night is my day, then I will repay it:
Till then she will trust me, wench is it not so,
And if it be, say aye, if not, say no.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Mother, good mother, hear me O good God,
Now we are even, what would you make us odd?
Now I beseech ye for the love of Christ,
To give me leave once to do what I list.
I am as you were when you were a maid,
Guess by yourself, how long you would have stayed,
Might you have had your will, as good begin,
At first as last, it saves us from much sin,
Lying alone, we muse on things and things,
And in our minds, one thought another brings,
This maids life mother is an idle life,
Therefore I will be, aye, I will be a wife,
And mother do not mistrust my age or power,
I am sufficient, I lack near an hour,
I had both wit to grant when he did woe me,
And strength to bear whatever he can do to me.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Well boldface, but I mean to make ye stay,
Go to, come from him, or I will make ye come,
Will ye not come?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother, I pray forbear,
This match is for my sister.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Villain it is not,
Nor she shall not be so matched now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In troth she shall, and your unruly hate,
Shall not rule us, we will end all this debate,
By this begun devise.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Aye end what you begun, villains, thieves,
Give me my daughter, will ye rob me of her?
Help, help, they will rob me here, they will rob me here.

div2.stage: Enter Maister Barnes and his men.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: How now, what outcry is here? why how now woman?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Why Gourseys son, confederates with this boy,
This wretch unnatural and undutiful,
Seeks hence to steal my daughter, will you suffer it?
Shall he that is son to my archenemy,
Enjoy her? have I brought her up to this?
O God he shall not have her, no he shall not.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: I am sorry she knows it, hark ye wife,
Let reason moderate your rage a little,
If you examine but his birth and living.
His wit and good behaviour, you will say,
Though that ill hate make your opinion bad,
He doth deserve as good a wife as she.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Why will you give consent he shall enjoy her?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Aye, so that thy mind would agree with mine.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: My mind shall near agree to this agreement.

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: And yet it shall go forward, but whois here?
What Mistress Goursey, how knew she of this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Franke, thy mother.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'swounds where? a plague upon it,
I think the devil is set to cross this match.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: This is the house Dick Coomes, and yonder is light,
Let us go near: how now, methinks I see
My son stand hand in hand, with Barnes his daughter;
Why how now sirrah, is this time of night,
for you to be abroad, what have we here?
I hope that love hath not thus coupled you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Love by my troth mother, love, she loves me,
And I love her, then we must needs agree.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Aye but I will keep her sure enough from thee.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: It shall not need, I will keep him safe enough,
Be sure he shall not graft in such a stock,

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: What stock forsooth? as good a stock as thine,
I do not mean that he shall graft in mine.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Not shall he mistress, hark boy? thou art but mad
To love the branch, that, hath a root so bad,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then mother, I will graft a Pippin on a Crab.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: It will not prove well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I will prove my skill.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Sir but you shall not.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mothers both I will.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Hark Phillip, send away thy sister straight,
Let Francis meet her where thou shalt appoint,
Let them go several to shun suspicion,
And bid them go to Oxford both this night.
There tomorrow say that we will meet them,
And there determine of their marriage.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will, though it be very late and dark,
My sister will endure it for a husband.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Well then at Carfolkes boy, I mean to meet them.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Enough, would they would begin to chide,
For I would have them brawling, that meanwhile,
They may steal hence, to meet where I appoint it:
What mother, will you let this match go forward:
Or mistress Goursey will you first agree?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Shall I agree first?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye why not, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Come from her son, if if thou lovest thy mother.

sp.speaker: Mi. Bar.
sp.l: With the like spell, daughter I conjure thee.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Francis, by fair mean, let me win thee from her,
And I will gild my blessing gentle son,
With store of Angels, I would not have thee
Check thy good fortune, by this cozening choice,
O do not thrall thy happy liberty,
In such a bondage, if thou wilt needs be bound,
Be then to better worth, this worthless choice
Is not fit for thee.

sp.speaker: Mist. Bar.
sp.l: Is it not fit for him, wherefore is it not fit?
Is he too brave a Gentleman I pray,
No it is not fit, she shall not fit his turn,
If she were wise, she would be fitter for
Three times his better, minion go in, or I will make ye
I will keep ye safe from him I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Come Francis, come from her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Mothers, with both hands, shove I hate from love,
That like an ill companion would infect,
The infant mind of our affection,
Within this cradle shall this minutes babe,
Be laid to rest, and thus I will hug my joy.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Wilt thou be obstinate, thou selfewild boy?
Nay then perforce I will part ye since ye will not.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Do ye hear mistress, pray ye give me leave to
talk two or three cold words with my young Master, hark
ye sir, ye are my masters son, and so forth, and indeed I
bear ye some good will, partly for his sake, and partly for
your own, and I do hope you do the like to me, I should be
sorry else: I must needs say ye are a young man, and for mine
own part, I have seen the world, and I know what belongs
to causes, and the experience that I have, I thank God I have
travelled for it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why how far have ye travelled for it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: From my masters house to the Alehouse.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: So sir,

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l:
Go to I pray, correct your boy, it was near a good
world, since a boy would face a man so.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Go to forward man.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l:
Well sir, so it is, I would not wish ye to marry without
my mistress consent.

sp.speaker: Franke.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
Nay, there is never a why, but there is a wherefore,
I have known some have done the like, and they have danced
a Galliard at Beggars bush for it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
At Beggars bush, hear him no more Master, he doth
bedawbe ye with his dirty speech: do ye hear sir, how
far stands Beggars bush from your fathers house sir? why
thou whoreson refuge of a Taylor, that wert prentice to a Taylor
half an age, and because if thou hadst served ten ages thou
wouldst prove but a botcher, thou leapest from the shop board
to a Blue coat: doth it become thee to use thy terms so?
well thou degree been above a hackney, and ten degrees under a
Page, sew up your lubber lips, or it is not your sword and
Buckler, shall keep my Poniard from your breast.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: Do ye hear sir, this is your boy.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: You must breech him for it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Must I? how if I will not.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
Why then it is a fine world, when boys keep boys,
and know not how to use them.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Boy, ye rascal.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Strike him if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: Strike me, alas he were better strike his father,
'swounds go to, put up your Bodkin.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mother stand by, I will teach that rascal.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
Go to, give me good words, or by Gods dines I will
buckle ye for all your birdspit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Will you so sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Staye Franke, this pitch of Frenzy will defile thee,
Meddle not with it, thy unreproved valour,
Should be high minded: couch it not so low,
Dost hear me? take occasion to slip hence,
But secretly, let not thy mother see thee,
At the back side there is a cony green,
Stay there for me, and Mall and I will come to thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Enough, I will: Mother you do me wrong,
To be so peremptory in your command,
And see that rascal to abuse me so.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
Rascal, take that and take all, do ye hear sir, I do
not mean to pocket up this wrong.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I know why that is.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Because you have never a pocket.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p:
A whip sirrah, a whip: but sir, provide your tools against
tomorrow morning, it is somewhat dark now indeed, you
know Dawsons close, between the hedge and the pond, it is
good even ground, I will meet you there, if I do not, call me
cut, if you be a man show yourself a man, we will have a
bout or two, and so we will part for that present.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Well sir, well.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Boy, have they appointed to fight?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Aye Nicholas, wilt not thou go see the fray?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
No indeed, even as they brew so let them bake, I
will not thrust my hand into the flame and need not, it is not
good to have an oar in another man's boat, little said is soon
amended, and in little meddling cometh great rest, it is good
sleeping in a whole skin, so a man might come home by weeping
cross: no by lady, a friend is not so soon gotten as lost,
blessed are the peacemakers, they that strike with the sword,
shall be beaten with the scabbard.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Well said proverbs, never another to that purpose?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Yes, I could have said to you sir, take heed is a good reed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why to me take heed?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: For happy is he whom other men's harms do make to beware,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O beware Franke, slip away Mall,
sp.p:
You know what I told ye I will hold our mothers both in talk
meanewhile: Mother and Mistress Barnes, methinks you
should not stand in hatred so hard one with another.

sp.speaker: Mi. Bar.
sp.l: Should I not sir? should I not hate a harlot,
That robs me of my right, vild boy?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: That title I return unto thy teeth,
And spit the name of harlot in thy face.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Well, it is not time of night to hold out chat,
With such a scold as thou art, therefore now,
Think that I hate thee as I do the devil.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: The devil take thee if thou dost not wretch.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Out upon thee strumpet.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Out upon thee harlot.

sp.speaker: Mis, Bar,
sp.l: Well, I will find a time to be revenged:
Mean time I will keep my daughter from thy son,
Where are ye minion? how now are ye gone.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She went in mother.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Francis, where are ye?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: He is not here, O then they slipped away, and both together.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I will assure ye no, my sister she went in, into the house.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: But then she will out again at the back door,
And meet with him, but I will search about
All these same fields and paths near to my house,
They are not far I am sure, if I make haste.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: O God how went he hence? I did not see him,
It was when Barnses wife did scold with me,
A plague upon her, Dick why didst not thou look to him?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
What should I look for him? no, no, I look not for
him while tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gour.
sp.l: Come go with me to help me look him out,
Alas, I have nor light, nor Link, nor Torch,
Though it be dark, I will take any pains,
To cross this match, I prithee Dicke away.

sp.speaker: Cooms.
sp.p:
Mistress, because I brought ye out, I will bring ye
home, but if I should follow, so he might have the law on his
side.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gou.
sp.l: Come it is no matter, prithee go with me.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Phillip, thy mother is gone to seek thy sister,
And in a rage Ifaith, but who comes here?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Old master Goursey, as I think it is he.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: It is so indeed.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Whois there?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: A friend of yours.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: What master Barnes did ye not see my wife?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Yes sir I saw her, she was here even now.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I doubted that, that made me come unto you:
But whether is she gone?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To seek your son, who slipped away from her,
To meet with Mall my sister in a place
Where I appointed: and my mother too,
Seeks for my sister, so they both are gone,
My mother hath a Torch, marry your wife
Goes darkling up and down, and Coomes before her.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I thought that knave was with her, but it is well,
I pray God they may come by never a light,
But both be led a dark dance in the night.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p:
Why is my fellow Dick in the dark with my Mistress,
I pray God they be honest, for there may be much knavery
in the Dark, faith if I were there, I would have some knavery
with them, good master will ye carry the torch yourself, and
give me leave to play at blind man buff with my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On that condition thou wilt do thy best,
To keep thy Mistress, and thy fellow Dicke,
Both from my sister, and thy masters son,
I will entreat thy Master let thee go.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: O aye, I warrant ye I will have fine tricks to cousin them.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Well sir, then go your ways, I give you leave.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: O brave, but where about are they?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: About our cony-green they surely are, if thou canst find them.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: O let me alone to grope for Cunnies.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, now will I to Franke and to my sister,
Stand you two harkening near the cony green,
But sure your light in you must not be seen,
Or else let Nicholas stand afar off with it.
And as his life keep it from Mistress Goursey.
Shall this be done?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Phillip it shall,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: God be with ye, I will be gone.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Come on master Goursey, this same is a means,
To make our wives friends, if they resist not.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Tut sir, howsoeuer it shall go forward.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Come then let us do, as Phillip hath advised.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: Here is the place where Phillip bad me stay,
Till Francis came, but wherefore did my brother
Appoint it here? why in the Cony borough?
He had some meaning in it I warrant ye
Well here I will set me down under this tree,
And think upon the matter all alone.
Good Lord what pretty things these Cunnies are,
How finely they do feed till they be fat,
And then what a sweet meat a Cony is,
And what smooth skins they have, both black and gray,
They say they run more in the night than day,
What is the reason? mark, why in the light,
They see more passengers than in the night,
for harmful men many a hay do set:
And laugh to see them tumble in the net,
And they put ferrets in the holes, fie, fie,
And they go up and down where conies lie,
And they lie still, they have so little wit,
I marvel the Warriner will suffer it,
Nay, nay, they are so bad, that they themselves
Do give consent to catch these pretty elves.
How if the Warriner should spy me here?
He would take me for a cony I dare swear.
But when that Francis comes, what will he say?
look boy there lies a cony in my way:
But soft, a light, who is that? soul my mother,
Nay then all hid, Ifaith she shall not see me,
I will play bopeep with her behind this tree.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: I marvel where this Wench do hide herself
So closely? I have searched in many a bush,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Belike my mother took me for a Thrush.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar,
sp.l: She is hid in this same Warren I will lay money.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Close as a rabbit sucker from an old cony.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: O God, I would to God that I could find her,
I would keep her from her loves toys yet.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Aye so you might if your daughter had no wit.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: What a vild girl it is that would have it so young.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A murrain take that dissembling tongue,
Ere your calves teeth were out you thought it long.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: But minion, yet I will keep you from the man.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To save a lie mother, say if you can.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Well, now to look for her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Aye there is the spite,
What trick shall I now have to scape her light?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Who is there? what minion is it you?
Beshrew her heart, what a fright she put me to,
But I am glad I found her, though I was afraid,
Come on your ways, you are a handsome maid.
Why you forth adoores so late at night?
Why whether go ye? come stand still I say.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No indeed mother, this is my best way.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: It is not the best way, stand by me I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No you would catch me mother, O I smell ye.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar
sp.l: Will ye not stand still?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No by Lady no.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: But I will make ye.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nay then trip and go.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Mistress, I will make ye weary ere I have done.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Faith mother then I will try how you can run,

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Will ye?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes faith.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Mal, sweetheart, Mal? what not a word?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A little further master call again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why Mal, I prithee speak, why Mal I say?
I know thou art not far, if thou wilt speak, why Mal,
But now I see she is in her merry vain,
To make me call and put me to more pain,
Well, I must bear with her, she will bear with me,
But I will call, least that it be not so,
What Mal? what Mall I say, boy are we right?
Have we not missed the way this same dark night?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Mass it may be so as I am true man,
I have not seen a cony since I came,
Yet at the cony-burrow we should meet,
But hark, I hear the trampling of some feet.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It may be so, then therefore let us lie close.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Where art thou Dicke?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Where am I quoth he, marry I may be where anybody
will say I am, either in France or at Room, or at Jerusalem
they may say I am, for I am not able to disprove them, because
I cannot tell where I am.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: O what a blindfold walk have we had Dicke,
To seek my son, and yet I cannot find him?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Why then Mistress let us go home.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Why it is so dark we shall not find the way.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I pray God ye may not moth till it be day.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: 'sblood take heed mistress here is a tree.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Lead thou the way, and let me hold by thee

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Dicke Coomes, what difference is there between a blind
man, and he that cannot see?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Peace, a pox on thee.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: 'swounds somebody spake.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Dicke look about,
It may be here we may find them out.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: I see the glimpse of somebody here,
If ye be a sprite I will fray the bug bear,
There he goes mistress.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: O sir have I spied you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A plague on the boy, it was he that descried me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How like a beauteous Lady masked in black,
Looks that same large circumference of heaven,
The sky that was so fair three hours ago,
Is in three hours become an Etheope,
And being angry at her beauteous change,
She will not have one of those pearled stars,
To blab her sable metamorphosis.
It is very dark, I did appoint my sister,
To meet me at the cony berry below,
And Francis too, but neither can I see,
Belike my mother happened on that place.
And afraid them from it, and they both are now
Wandering about these fields, how shall I find them?
It is so dark, I scarce can see my hand,
Why then I will hollow for them, no not so,
So will his voice betray him to our mothers,
And if he answer, and bring them where he is.
What shall I then do? it must not be so?
'sblood it must be so, how else I pray?
Shall I stand gaping here all night till day?
And then be never the near, So ho, so ho.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So ho, I come, where are ye? where art thou? here.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How now Franke? where hast been?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Franke, what Franke? 'sblood is sir Raph mad, here is the bow

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I have not been much private with that voice,
Methinks Franke Gousies talk and his doth tell me,
I am mistaken, especially by his bow,
Franke had no bow, well, I will leave this fellow,
And hollow somewhat farther in the fields,
Dost thou hear fellow, I perceive by thee,
That we are both mistaken, I took thee
for one thou art not, likewise thou tookest me
For sir Raph Smith, but sure I am not he,
And so farewell, I must go seek my friend, so ho:

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So ho, so ho, nay then sir Raph so whore,
For a whore she was sure, if you had her here
So late, now you are sir Raph Smith,
Well do ye counterfeit and change your voice,
But yet I knew ye, but what should be that Francis?
Belike that Francis cozened him of his wench,
And he conceals himself to find her out,
it is so upon my life, well I will go
And help him ring his peal so ho, so ho,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A plague on Coomes, a plague upon the boy,
A plague too, not on my mother for an hundredth pound,
It was time to run, and yet I had not thought
My mother could have followed me so close,
Her legs with age I thought had foundered,
She made me quite run through a quickset hedge,
Or she had taken me: well I may say,
I have run through the briers for a wench,
And yet I have her not, the worse luck mine,
Methought I heard one hollow here about,
I judge it Phillip, O the slave will laugh
When as he hears how that my mother scared me,
Well, here I will stand until I hear him hollow,
And then I will answer him, he is not far.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: My man is hollowing for me up and down,
And yet I cannot meet with him, so ho:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Why what a pox, wert thou so near me man,
And wouldst not speak?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'sblood ye are very hot.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: No sir I am cold enough with staying here
For such a knave as you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Knave, how now Phillip? art mad, art mad?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why art not thou my man?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Indeed a bow,
Might shoot me ten bows down the weather so,
I your man.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: What art thou then?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A man, but what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Some call me Raph.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then honest Raph farewell.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Well said familiar Will, plain Raph Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There calls my man.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But there goes mine away.
And yet I will hear what this next call will say,
And here I will tarry till he call again.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So ho, where art thou Phillip?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: But now he called me Francis, this is fine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why studiest thou? I prithee tell me Phillip,
Where the wench is?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Even now he asked me Francis for the wench,
And now he asked me Phillip for the wench,
Well sir Raph I must needs tell ye now,
it is not for your credit to be forth,
So late awenching in this order.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What is this, so late awenching doth he say?
Indeed it is true, I am thus late awenching,
But I am forced to wench without a wench.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Why then you might have taken your bow at first,
And gone and killed a buck, and not have been
So long adrabbing, and be never the near.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'swounds what a pussel am I in this night,
But yet I will put this fellow farther,
Dost thou hear man? I am not sir Raph Smith,
As thou dost think I am, but I did meet him,
Even as thou sayst in pursuit of a wench,
I met the wench too, and she asked for thee,
Saying it was thou that wert her love, her dear,
And that sir Raph was not an honest knight,
To train her thither, and to use her so.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: 'sblood my wench, 'swounds were he ten sir Raphes .

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay it is true, look to it, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Indeed I do love Nan our dairy maid,
And hath he train her forth to that intent?
Or for another, I carry his crossbow,
And he doth cross me, shooting in my bow,
What, shall I do?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: So ho?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Francis art thou there?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: No here is no Francis, art thou Will my man?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Will fool your man, will as go your man,
My back sir scorns to wear your livery.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Nay sir I moved but such a question to you,
And it hath not disparaged you I hope,
It was but mistaking, such a night as this
May well deceive a man, God boy sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Gods will it is sir Raph Smith, a virtuous knight,
How gently entertains he my hard answer?
Rude anger made my tongue unmannerly
I cry him mercy, well, but all this while,
I cannot find a Francis, Francis ho?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Francis ho, O you call Francis now,
How have ye used my Nan? come tell me how.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thy Nan, what Nan?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Aye, what Nan now, say, do you not seek a wench?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yes I do.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Then sir that is she.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Art not thou I met withal before?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: Yes sir, and you did counterfeit before,
And said to me you were not sir Raph Smith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No more I am not, I met sir Raph Smith,
Even now he asked me if I saw his man.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: O fine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why sirrah thou art much deceived in me,
Good faith I am not he thou thinkst I am.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: What are ye then?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why one that seeks one Francis and a wench.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: And Francis seeks one Phillip and a wench.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I met him seeking Phillip and a wench,
As I was seeking sir Raph and a wench.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why then I know the matter, we met cross,
And so we missed, now here we find our loss,
Well, if thou wilt, we two will keep together,
And so we shall meet right with one or other.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: I am content, but do you hear me sir?
Did not sir Raph Smith ask ye for a wench?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No I promise thee, nor did he look for any
But thyself, as I could guess.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.l: why this is strange, but come sir let us away,
I fear that we shall walk here till it be day.

sp.p:
O God I have run so far into the wind, that
I have run myself out of wind, they say a man is near his
end when he lacks breath, and I am at the end of my race, for
I can run no farther than here I be in my breath bed, not in my
death bed.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
They say men moil and toil for a poor living, so I
moil and toil, and am living I thank God, in good time
be it spoken, it had been better for me my mistress angel had
been light, for then perhaps it had not lead me into this
darkness, well, the devil never blesses a man better, when he
purses up angels by owl light, I ran through a hedge to
take the boy, but I stuck in the ditch, and lost the boy: 'swounds
a plague on that clod, that nowhile, that ditch, or what the devil
soere it were, for a man cannot see what it was, well, I would
not for the prize of my sword and buckler, anybody should
see me in this taking, for it would make me but cut off their legs
for laughing at me, well, down I am, and down I mean to
be, because I am weary, but to tumble down thus, it was no
part of my meaning, then since I am down, here I will rest me,
and no man shall remove me.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
O I have sport in cony In faith, I have almost burst
myself with laughing at mistress Barnes, she was following
of her daughter, and I hearing her, put on my fellow Dickes
sword and buckler, voice, and his 'swounds and 'sblood words,
and led her such a dance in the dark as it passes, here she is
quoth I, where quoth she? here quoth I, O it hath been a brave
here and there night, but O what a softnatured thing the dirt is?
how it would endure my hard treading, and kiss my feet for
acquaintance, and how courteous and mannerly were the
clothes, to make me stumble only of purpose to entreat
me lie down and rest me, but now if I could find my fellow
Dicke, I would play the knave with him honestly Ifaith, Well,
I will grope in the dark for him, or I will poke with my staff like
a blind man, to prevent a ditch.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Who is, that with a pox?

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: Who art thou with a pestilence?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Why I am Dicke Coomes?

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p:
What have I found thee Dicke? nay then I am for ye
Dicke, Where are ye Dicke?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: What can I tell where I am?

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p:
Can ye not tell, come, come, ye weight on your mistress
well, come on your ways I have sought you till I am
weary, and called ye till I am hoarse, good Lord what a jaunt I
have had this night, hey ho?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Is it, you mistress that came over me, 'sblood it were a
good deed to come over you for this nights work, I cannot
afford all this pains for an angel I tell ye true, a kiss were
not cast away, upon a good fellow, that hath deserved more
that way than a kiss, if your kindness would afford it him,
What, shall I have it mistress?

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: Fie, fie, I must not kiss my man.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, never stand, shall I? shall I? nobody, sees,
say but I shall, and I will smack ye soundly In faith.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: Away bawdy man, in truth I will tell your master.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
My master, go to, never tell me of my master, he may
pray for them that may, he is past it, and for mine own part, I
can do somewhat that way I thank God, I am not now to
learn, and it is your part to have your whole desire.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.p:
Fie,
fie, I am ashamed of you, would you tempt your mistress to
lewdness?

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
To lewdness, no by my troth, there is no such matter
in it, it is for kindness, and by my troth if you like my gentle
offer, you shall have what courteously I can afford ye.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
Shall I indeed Dicke? Ifaith, if I thought nobody
would see.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p: Tush, fear not that, 'swounds they must have Cats eyes then.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: Then kiss me Dick.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: A kind wench Ifaith, where are ye Mistress?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: Here Dick, o I am in the dark, Dick go about.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Nay, I will grope sure, where are ye?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
A plague on this post, I would the Carpenter had
been hanged that set it up for me, where are ye now?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Here, O I come, a plague on it, I am in a pond mistress.

sp.speaker: Hod.
sp.l: Ha, ha, I have led him into a pond, where art thou Dick?

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: Up to the middle in a pond.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p:
Make a Boat of thy Buckler then, and swim out, are
ye so hot with a pox? would you kiss my mistress, cool ye
there then good Dick Coomes, O when he comes forth, the
skirts of his Blue coat will drop like a painthouse, O that I
could see and not be seen, how he would Spaniel it, and shake
himself when he comes out of the pond, but I will be gone, for
now he will fight with a fly, if he but buzz in his ear.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Here is so hoing with a plague, so hang if ye will
for I have been almost drowned, a pox of your lips, if ye call
this kissing: ye talk of a drowned Rat, but it was time to swim
like a Dog, I had been served like a drowned Cat else, I would he
had digged his grave that digged the pond, my feet were foul indeed,
but a less pale than a pond would have served my turn
to wash them: a man shall be served thus always, when he
follows any of these females, but it is my kind heart that makes
me thus forward in kindness unto them, well God amend them,
and make them thankful to them that would do
them pleasure,
I am not drunk I would ye should well know it, and yet I
have drunk more than will do me good, for I might have had a
Pump set up, with as good March Beer as this was, and never
set up an Ale bush for the matter: well I am somewhat in wroth,
I must needs say, and yet I am not more angry than wise, nor
more wise than angry, but I will fight with the next man I meet,
if it be but for luck sake, and if he love to see himself hurt,
let him bring light with him, I will do it by darkling else by gods
dines, well here will I walk whosoever says nay.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
He that worse may must hold the Candle, but my
Master is not so wise as God might have made him, he is
gone to seek a Hair in a Hens nest, a Needle in a Bottle
of Haye, which is as seldom seen as a black Swan: he is
gone to seek my young Mistress, and I think she is better
lost than found, for whosoever hath her, hath but a wet
Eel by the tail, but they may do as they list, the law is in their
own hands, but if they would be ruled by me, they should
set her on the Leland, and bid the Devil split her, beshrew her
fingers she hath made me watch past mine hour, but I will
watch her a good turn for it.

sp.speaker: Cooms.
sp.p:
How, who is that Nicholas? so, first come first served,
I am for him: how now proverb, proverb, 'sblood how now
proverb?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
My name is Nicholas, Richard: and I know your
meaning, and I hope ye mean no harm: I thank ye I am
the better for your asking.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Where have you been awhoring thus late, ha?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Master Richard the good wife would not seek her
daughter in the Oven unless she had been there herself, but
good Lord you are knuckle deep in dirt, I warrant when
he was in, he swore Walsingham, and chaste terrible for the
time, look the water drops from you as fast as hops.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
What needst thou to care, whipperIenny, Tripecheeke,
out you fat ass.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Good words cost naught, ill words corrupts good
manners Richard, for a hasty man never wants woe, and I had
thought you had been my friend, but I see all is not gold that
glisters, there is falsehood in fellowship, a micus certus in re certa
cernitur, time and truth tries all, and it is an old Proverb, and
not so old as true, Bought wit is the best, I can see day at a little
hole, I know your mind as well as though I were within you,
it is ill halting before a cripple, go to, you seek to quarrel, but
beware of had I wist: so long goes the pot to the water, at
length it comes home broken, I know you are as good a man
as ever drew sword, or as was ever girt in a girdle, or as ever went
on Neats leather, or as one shall see upon a summers day, or as
ever looked man in the face, or as ever trod on Gods earth, or as
ever broke bread, or drunk drink: but he is proper that hath
proper conditions, but be not you like the Cow that gives a
good sop of milk and casts it down with his heels, I speak
plainly, for plain dealing is a Jewel, and he that useth it shall
die a beggar, well, that happens in a hour, that happens not
in seven years, a man is not so soon whole as hurt, if you
should kill a man, you would kiss his: well, I say little, but I
think the more yet I will give him good words, it is good to hold
a candle before the devil, yet by Gods me, I will take no wrong,
if he had a head as big as Brass, or looked as high as Paul's
steeple.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Sirrah, thou Grasshopper, that shalt skip from my sword
as from a Sith, I will cut thee out in collops and eggs, in steaks,
in sliced beef, and fry thee with the fryer I shall strike from the
pike of thy Buckler.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Aye, brags a good dog, threatened folks live long.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: What say ye sir?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Why I say not so much as how do ye.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Do ye not so sir?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: No indeed, whatsoere I think, and thought is free.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
You whoreson Wafercake, by Gods dines I will
crush ye for this.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Give an inch and you will take an ell, I will not put
my finger in a hole I warrant ye what man, never crow so
fast, for a blind man may kill a Hare, I have known when
a plain fellow hath hurt a Fencer, so I have: What, a man
may be as slow as a Snail, but as fierce as a Lion if he
be moved: Indeed I am patient I must needs say, for patience
in adversity, brings a man to the three Cranes in the
Ventree.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
Do ye hear, set down your Torch, draw, fight,
I am for ye.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
And I am for ye too, though it be from this midnight
to the next morn.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: Where be your tools?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Within a mile of an oak sir, he is a proud horse will
not carry his own provender, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Now am I in my quarrelling humour, and now can I
say nothing but 'swounds draw, but I will untruss, and then have to it.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
Who is, there, Boy? honest Boy, well met, where
hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
O Hodge, Dicke coomes hath been as good as a cry
of Hounds, to make a breathed Hare of me, but didst thou see
my master?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
I met him even now, and he asked me for thee, and
he is gone up and down, whoing like an Owl for thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Owl, ye Ass.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
Ass, no nor glass, for then it had been Owlglass,
but who is that Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
By the mass it is our Coomes and Nicholas, and it seems
they are providing to fight.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
Then we shall have fine sport, Ifaith sirrah, let us stand
close, and when they have fought a bout or two, we will run
away with the Torch, and leave them to fight darkling, shall we?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Content, I will get the Torch, stand close.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
So now my back hath room to reach, I do not
love to be laced in, when I go to lace a rascal, I pray God Nicholas
prove not a fly: it would do me good to deal with
a good man now, that we might have half a dozen good
smart strokes, ha I have seen the day, I could have danced in
my fight, one, two, three, four and five, on the head of him:
six, seven, eight, nine and ten, on the sides of him, and if I went
so far as fifteen, I warrant I showed him a trick of one and twenty:
but I have not fought this four days, and I lack a little
practise of my ward, but I shall make a shift, ha close, are ye
disposed sir?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Yes indeed, I fear no colours, change sides Richard.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: Change the gallows, I will see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
Well, I see the fool will not leave his babble for the
Tower of London.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.l: Fool ye Rogue, nay then fall to it.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Good Goose bite not.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
'sblood how pursy I am, well I see exercise is all, I
must practise my weapons oftener, I must have a goal or two
at Football, before I come to my right kind, give me thy
hand Nicholas, thou art a better man than I took thee for,
and yet thou art not so good a man as I.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
You dwell by ill neighbours Richard, that makes ye
praise yourself.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.l: Why I hope thou wilt say I am a man?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Yes I will say so, if I should see ye hanged.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
Hanged ye Rogue, nay then have at ye, 'swounds the
light is gone.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: O Lord, it is as dark as Pitch.

sp.speaker: Coomes.
sp.p:
Well here I will lie with my Buckler thus, least striking
up and down at randall, the rogue might hurt me, for I
cannot see to save it, and I will hold my peace, least my voice
should bring him where I am.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
It is good to have a cloak for the rain, a bad shift is
better than none at all, I will sit here as if I were as dead as a
door nail.

div2.stage: Enter M. Barnes and M. Goursey.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Hark, there is one holloes.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: And there is another.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: And euerywhere we come, I hear some holla.
And yet it is our haps to meet with none.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: I marvel where your Hodge is, and my man?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Aye and our wives, we cannot meet with them,
Nor with the boy, nor Mall, nor Franke, nor Phillip:
Nor yet with Coomes, and yet we never stood still.
Well I am very angry with my wife,
And she shall find I am not pleased with her,
If we meet never so soon, but it is my hap,
She hath had as blind a journey of it as we,
Pray God she have, and worse if worse may be.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: This is but shortliu'd envy Master Goursey:
But come, what say ye to my policy?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Ifaith it is good, and we will practise it,
But sir it must be handled cunningly,
Or all is marred, our wives have subtle heads,
And they will soon perceive a drift devise.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Who is, there?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Here is one or two.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Is Will there?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: No, Phillip?

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Franke?

sp.speaker: S. Raph.
sp.l: No, no.
Was ever man deluded thus like me,
I think some spirit leads me thus amiss:
As I have often heard, that some have been thus in the nights.
But yet this amazes me whereere I come.
Some asks me still for Franke or Phillip,
And none of them can tell me where Will is.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So ho?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: So ho?

sp.speaker: Boye.
sp.l: So ho?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: 'swounds now I hear four hollo at the least,
One had a little voice, then that is the wench
My man hath lost, well I will answer all, so ho.

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.l: Whoopee, whoopee.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Who is, there will?

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
No sir, honest Hodge: but I pray
ye sir did ye not
meet with a boy with a Torch, he is run away from me
a plague on him.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Hey day, from Franke and Phillip to a Torch,
And to a Boy, nay 'swounds then hap as it will.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Guess here.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Phillip.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Phillip, no faith, my name is Will, ill will, for I was never
worse, I was even now with him, and might have been
still, but that I fell into a ditch and lost him, and now I am going
up and down to seek him.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: What wouldst thou do with him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Why I would have him go with me to my masters.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Who is thy master?

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p:
Why sir Raphe Smith, and thither he promised me he
would come, if he keep his word so it is.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: What was he doing when thou first foundest him,

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Why he holloed for one Frauncis, and Frauncis holloed
for him, I hallooed for my master, and my master for me, but we
missed still meeting contrary, Phillip and Francis with me and my
master, and I and my master with Phillip and Franke.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: Why wherefore is sir Raphe so late abroad?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Why he meant to kill a Buck, I will say so to save his honesty,
but my Nan was his mark, and he sent me for his bow,
and when I came, I holloed for him, but I never saw such luck
to miss him, it hath almost made me mad.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Well stay with us, perhaps sir Raphe and he,
Will come anon, hark I do hear one hollo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is this broad waking in a winters night,
I am broad walking in a winters night:
Broad indeed, because I am abroad,
But these broad fields methinks are not so broad,
That they may keep me forth of narrow ditches,
Here is a hard world, for I can hardly keep myself upright in it,
I am marvelous dutiful, but so ho.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: So ho.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Here is will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What Will, how scapest thou?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, not hanging, but drowning,
Wert thou in a pond or a ditch?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
A pestilence on it, is it you Phillip, no faith, I was but
dirty a little, but here is one or two asked for ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who be they man?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Philip, it is I and Master Goursey.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father, O Father I have heard them say,
The days of ignorance are past and done,
But I am sure the nights of ignorance
Are not yet past, for this is one of them,
But where is my sister?

sp.speaker: M. Ba.
sp.l: Why we cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why this is fine.
What neither he, nor I, nor she nor you,
Nor I, not she, nor you, and I tell now,
Can meet, could meet, or ere I think shall meet,
Call ye this wooing, no it is Christmas sport of Hob man blind,
All blind, all seek to catch, all miss: but who comes here?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O have I catched ye sir, it was your doing,
That made me have this pretty dance tonight,
Had not you spoke, my mother had not scared me,
But I will swing ye for it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Keep the Kings peace.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How? art thou become a Constable?
Why Phillip where hast thou been all this while?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why where you were not, but I pray where is my sister?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Why man I saw her not, but I have sought her as I
should seek.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A Needle have ye not?
Why you man are the needle that she seeks,
To work withal, well Francis do you hear,
You must not answer so, that you have sought her,
But have ye found her, faith and if you have,
God give ye joy of that ye found with her,
I saw her not, how could I find her.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.p:
Why could ye miss from Master Barnses house
unto his Cony berry?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Whether I could nor no, father I did.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Father I did, well Franke wilt thou believe me,
Thou dost not know how much this fame doth grieve me:
Shall it be said thou missed so plain a way,
When as so fair a wench did for thee stay.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'swounds man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'swounds man, and if thou hadst been blind,
The cony-burrow thou needst must find:
I tell thee Francis, had it been my case,
And I had been a wooer in thy place,
I would have laid my head unto the ground,
And scented out my wenches way like a Hound:
I would have crept upon my knees all night,
And have made the flintstones Links to give me light,
Nay man I would.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good Lord what you would do,
Well we shall see one day how you can woe.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Come, come, we see that we have all been crossed,
Therefore let us go, and seek them we have lost.
Am I alone? doth not my mother come?
Her torch I see not, which I well might see,
If any way she were coming toward me,
Why then belike she is gone some other way,
And may she go till I bid her turn,
Far shall her way be then, and little fair,
for she hath hindered me of my good turn,
God send her wet and weary ere she turn,
I had been at Oxenford, and tomorrow,
Have been released from all my maidens sorrow,
And tasted joy, had not my mother been,
God I beseech thee make it her worst sin,
How many maids this night lies in their beds,
And dream that they have lost their maidenheads,
Such dreams, such slumbers I had too enjoyed,
If waking malice had not them destroyed,
A starved man with double death doth die,
To have the meat might save him in his eye,
And may not have it, so am I tormented,
To starve for joy I see, yet am prevented,
Well Franke, although thou wooedest and quickly won,
Yet shall my love to thee be never done,
I will run through hedge and ditch, through breaks and briers,
To come to thee, sole Lord of my desires,
Short wooing is the best, an hour, not years,
For long debating, love is full of fears,
But hark, I hear one tread, O were it my brother,
Or Franke, or any man, but not my mother.

sp.speaker: S. Rap.
sp.l: O when will this same year of night have end?
Long lookt-for days sun, when wilt thou ascend?
Let not this thief friend misty vale of night,
Encroach on day, and shadow thy fair light,
Whilst thou comest tardy from thy Thetis bed,
Blushing forth golden hair and glorious red,
O stay not long bright lantern of the day,
To light my missed way feet to my right way.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: It is a man, his big voice tells me so,
Much am I not acquainted with it though,
And yet mine ear sounds true distinguisher,
Boys that I have been more familiar
With it than now I am, well, I do judge,
It is not envies felon not of grudge,
Therefore I will plead acquaintance, hire his guiding,
And buy of him some place of close abiding,
Till that my moths malice be expired,
And we may joy in that is long desired, who is there?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Are ye a maid? no question this is she,
My man doth miss, faith since she lights on me,
I do not mean till day to let her go,
For what she is my man's love I will know,
Hark ye maid, if maid, are ye so light,
That you can see to wander in the night?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hark ye true man, if true, I tell ye no,
I cannot see at all which way I go.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Fair maid is it so, say, had ye never a fall?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Fair man not so, no I had none at all.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Could you not stumble on one man I pray?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No, no, such block till now came in my way.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Am I that block sweet tripe, then fall and try.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The ground is too hard, a feather bed, not I.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why how if you had met with such a stump?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why if he had been your height I meant to jump.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Are ye so nimble?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Nimble as a Doe.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Baked in a Pie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Of ye.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Good meat ye know.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ye hunt sometimes,

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What take ye?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Dear.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: You will never strike rascal?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes when ye are there.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Will ye strike me?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Yes, will ye strike again?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No sir, it fits not maids to fight with men,

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I wonder wench how I thy name might know.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why you may find it sir in the Christcrosse row.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Be my Schoolmistress, teach me how to spell it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No faith, I care not greatly if I tell it,
My name is Marry Barnes.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: How wench, Mall Barnes?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Why this is strange.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I pray sir what is your name?

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: why sir Raph Smith doth wonder wench at this,
Why what is the cause thou art abroad so late?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What sir Raph Smith, nay then I will disclose,
All the whole cause to him, in him repose,
My hopes, my love, God him I hope did send,
Our loves and both our mothers hates to end,
Gentle sir Raph if you my blush might see,
You then would say I am ashamed to be
Found like a wandering stray by such a knight,
So far from home at such a time of night,
But my excuse is good, love first by fate,
Is crossed, controlled, and sundered by fell hate,
Franke Goursey is my love, and he loves me,
But both our mothers hate and disagree,
Our fathers like the match, and wish it done,
And so it had, had not our mothers come,
To Oxford we concluded both to go,
Going to meet, they came, we parted so,
My mother followed me, but I ran fast,
Thinking who went from hate had need make haste,
Take me she cannot though she still pursue,
But now sweet knight, I do repose on you,
Be you my Orator and plead my right,
And get me one good day for this bad night.

sp.speaker: Rap.
sp.l: Alas good heart, I pity thy hard hap,
And I will employ all that I may for thee,
Franke Goursey wench, I do commend thy choice,
Now I remember I met one Francis
As I did seek my man, then that was he,
sp.p:
And Philip too, belike that was thy brother, Why now I find
how I did loose myself, And wandering up and down, mistaking
so, Give me thy hand Mall, I will never leave,
sp.l: Till I have made your mothers friends again,
And purchased to ye both your hearts delight,
And for this same one bad, many a good night,
It will not be long ere that Aurora will
Decked in the glory of a golden sun,
Open the crystal windows of the East,
To make the earth enamoured of her face,
When we shall have clear light to see our way,
Come, night being done, expect a happy day.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: O what a race this peevish girl hath led me?
How fast I ran, and now how weary I am,
I am so out of breath I scarce can speak,
What shall I do? and cannot overtake her,
It is late and dark, and I am far from home,
May there not thieves lie watching here about,
Intending mischief unto them they meet,
There may, and I am much afraid of them,
Being alone without all company,
I do repent me of my coming forth,
And yet I do not, they had else been married,
And that I would not for ten times more labour,
But what a winter of cold fear I stole,
Freezing my heart least danger should betide me,
What shall I do to purchase company?
I hear some hollow here about the fields,
Then here I will set my torch upon this hill,
Whose light shall beacon-like conduct them to it,
They that have lost their way seeing a light,
for it may be seen far off in the night,
Will come to it, well, here I will lie unseen,
And look who comes, and choose my company,
Perhaps my daughter may first come to it.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Where am I now? nay where was I even now,
Nor now, nor then, nor where I shall be, know I,
I think I am going home, I may as well
Being going from home, it is so very dark,
I cannot see how to direct a step,
I lost my man pursuing of my son,
My son escaped me too, now all alone,
I am enforced to wander up and down,
Barnses wife is abroad, pray God that she,
May have as good a dance, nay ten times worse
O but I fear she hath not, she hath light
To see her way, O that same bridge would break,
That she might fall into some deep-digged ditch,
And either break her bones or drown herself,
I would these mischiefs I could wish to her,
Might light on her, but soft I see a light,
I will go near, it is comfortable,
After this nights sad spirits dulling darkness,
How now? what is it set to keep itself?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: A plague on it, is she there?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: O how it cheers and quickens up my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: O that it were the Basilisks fell eye,
To poison thee.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: I care not if I take it,
Sure none is here to hinder me,
And light me home.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: I had rather she were hanged,
Than I should set it there to do her good,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Ifaith I will.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Ifaith you shall not mistress.
I will venture a burnt finger but I will have it:

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Yet Barnses wife would chase if that she knew,
That I had this good luck to get a light.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: And so she doth but praise your luck at parting.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: O that it were her light good faith, that she,
Might darkling walk about as well as I,

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: O how this mads me, that she hath her wish,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: How I would laugh to see her trot about.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: O, I could cry for anger and for rage.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: But who should set it here I marvel in gods name?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: One that will have it from you in the devils name.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: I will lay my life that it was Barnses son.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: No forsooth, it was Barnses wife.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: A plague upon her, how she made me start?
Mistress let go the torch.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: No but I will not.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: I will thrust it in thy face then.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: But you shall not.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Let go I say.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Let you go, for it is mine,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: But my possession says it is none of thine.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Nay, I have hold too,

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Well, let go thy hold, or I will spurn thee.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Do, I can spurn thee too.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Canst thou?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Aye that I can.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Why how now women, how unlike to women
Are ye both now? come part, come part I say.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Why what immodesty is this in you?
Come part I say, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Fie, fie, I say she shall not have my torch,
Give me thy torch boy, I will run a tilt,
And burn out both her eyes in my encounter.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Give room and let us have this hot carer.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: I say ye shall not, wife go to, tame your thoughts,
That are so mad with fury.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: And sweet wife,
Temper your rage with patience, do not be
Subject so much to such misgovernment.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: shall I not sir, when such a strumpet wrongs me?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: How, strumpet mistress Barnes? nay I pray hark ye,
I oft indeed have heard ye call her so,
And I have thought upon it, why ye should
Twit her with name of strumpet,
Do you know any hurt by her, that you term her so?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: No on my life, rage only makes her say so.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: But I would know whence this same rage should come,
Where is smoke, there is fire, and my heart misgives.
My wives intemperance hath got that name,
And mistress Barnes, I doubt and shroudly doubt,
And some great cause begets this doubt in me,
Your husband and my wife doth wrong us both.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: How? think ye so, nay master Goursey then
You run in debt to my opinion,
Because you pay not such advised wisdom,
As I think due unto my good conceit.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Then still I fear I shall your debtor prove.
Then I arrest you in the name of love,
Not bale, but present answer to my plea,
And in the Court of reason we will try,
If that good thoughts should believe jealousy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why look ye mother, this is long of you,
for Gods sake father hark, why these effects
Come still from women's malice: part I pray,
Comes, Wil, and Hodge come all and help us part them,
Father, but hear me speak one word, no more:

sp.speaker: Franke.
sp.l: Father, but hear him speak, then use your will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Cry peace between ye for a little while.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Good husband hear him speak.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Good husband hear him.

sp.speaker: Coom.
sp.p:
Master hear him speak, he is a good wise young
stripling, for his years I tell ye, and perhaps may speak wiser
than an elder body, therefore hear him.

sp.speaker: Hodg.
sp.p:
Master hear him and make an end, you may kill one another
in jest, and be hanged in earnest.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Come let us hear him, then speak quickly Phillip.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Thou shouldest have don ere this, speak Phillip speak:

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: O Lord what haste you make to hurt yourselves,
Good Phillip use some good persuasions
To make them friends.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Yes, I will do what I can,
Father and master Goursey both attend,
It is presumption in so young a man,
To teach where he might learn or be directed,
Where he hath had direction but in duty,
He may persuade as long as his persuasion,
Is backed with reason and a rightful suit,
Physics first rule is this, as I have learned,
sp.p:
Kill the effect by cutting off the cause, The same effects of ruffian
outrages, Comes by the cause of malice in your wives,
sp.l: Had not they two been foes, you had been friends,
And we had been at home, and this same war,
In peaceful sleep had near been dreamt upon
Mother, and mistress Goursey to make them friends,
Is to be friends yourselves, you are the cause,
And these effects proceed you know from you,
Your hates give life unto these killing strifes,
But die, and if that envy die in you,
Fathers yet stay, O speak, O stay a while,
Francis persuade thy mother, master Goursey,
If that my mother will resolve your minds,
That it is but mere suspect, not common proof,
And if my father swear he is innocent,
As I durst pawn my soul with him he is.
And if your wife vow truth and constancy,
Will you be then persuaded?

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Phillip, if thy father will remit,
the wounds I gave him, and if these conditions
May be performed, I banish all my wrath.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: And if thy mother will but clear me Phillip,
As I am ready to protest I am,
Then master Goursey is my friend again.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hark mother, now you hear that your desires
May be accomplished, they will both be friends,
If you will perform these easy articles.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Shall I be friends with such an enemy?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What say you unto my persuasion?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: I say she is my deadly enemy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye But she will be your friend if you revolt.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: The words I said, What shall I eat a truth?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why hark ye mother.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Mother what say you?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: Why this I say, she slandered my good name.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But if she now deny it, it is no defame.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: What, shall I think her hate will yield so much?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why doubt it not, her spirit may be such,

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Why will it be?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yet stay, I have some hope,
Mother, why mother, why hear ye,
Give me your hand, it is no more but thus,
It is easy labour to shake hands with her.
A little breath is spent in speaking of fair words,
When wrath hath violent delivery.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: What shall we be resolved?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: O husband stay.
Stay Master Goursey, though your wife doth hate me,
And bears unto me malice infinite,
And endless, yet I will respect your safeties,
I would not have you perish by our means,
I must confess that only suspect,
And no proof else, hath fed my hate to her.

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: And husband I protest by heaven and earth,
That her suspect is causeless and unjust,
And that I never had such a vild intent,
Harm she imagined, whereas none was meant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lo sir, what would ye more?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Yes Phiilip this.
That I confirm him in my Innocence,
By this large universe.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: By that I swear, I will credit none of you, until I hear
Friendship concluded straight between them two,
If I see that they willingly will do,
Then I will imagine all suspicion ends,
I may be then assured they being friends.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother make full my wish, and be it so.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: What shall I sue for friendship to my foe?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, if she yield will you?

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: It may be I.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why this is well, the other I will try,
Come mistress Goursey, do you first agree?

sp.speaker: Mis. Gou.
sp.l: What shall I yield unto mine enemy?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why if she will, will you?

sp.speaker: Mi. Gou.
sp.l: Perhaps I will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay then I find this goes well forward still:
Mother give me your hand, give me yours too,
Be not so loath, some good thing I must do,
But lay your Torches by, I like not them,
Come, come, deliver them unto your men,
Give me your hands, so now sir here I stand,
Holding two angry women in my hand,
And I must please them both, I could please the one,
But it is hard when there is two to one,
Especially of women, but it is so,
They shall be pleased whether they will or no,
Which will come first? what both give back, ha, neither?
Why then yond may help that come both together,
So stand still, stand but a little while,
And see how I your angers will beguile,
Well yet there is no hurt, why then let me
Join these two hands, and see how they will agree,
Peace, peace, they cry, look how they friendly kiss,
Well all this while there is no harm in this,
Are not these two twins? twins should be both alike,
If the one speaks fair, the other should not strike,
Iesus these warriors will not offer blows,
Why then it is strange that you two should be foes,
O yes, you will say your weapons are your tongues,
Touch lip with lip and they are bound from wrongs.
Go to, embrace and say if you be friends,
That here the angry women's quarrels ends.

sp.speaker: Mi. Gour.
sp.l: Then here it ends, if mistress Barnes say so.

sp.speaker: Mi. Bar.
sp.l: If you say aye, I list not to say no.

sp.speaker: M. Gour.
sp.l: If they be friends, by promise we agree,

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: And may this league of friendship ever be.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What sayst thou Franke, doth not this fall out well?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes if my Mall were here, then all were well.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Raphe Smith with Mall.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Yonder they be Mall, stay, stand close and stir not
Until I call: God save ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: What sir Raphe Smith you are a welcome man,
We wondered when we heard you were abroad.

sp.speaker: S. Raph.
sp.l: Why sir, how heard ye that I was abroad?

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: By your man.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: My man, where is he?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Here:

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: O ye are a trusty squire.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: It had been better and he had said, a sure card.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: Because it is the Proverb.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Away ye Ass.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: An Ass goes a four legs, I go of two, Christ cross.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: And make no more ado.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Go to, no more do, gentle sir Raphe,
Your man is not in fault for missing you,
for he mistook by us and we by him.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: And I by you, which now I well perceive,
But tell me Gentlemen, what made ye all,
Be from your beds this night, and why thus late
Are your wives walking here about the fields?
it is strange to see such women of account,
Here, but I guess some great occasion,

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: Faith this occasion sir, women will jar,
And jar they did today, and so they parted,
We knowing women's malice let alone,
Will Canker-like eat farther in their hearts,
Did seek a sudden cure, and thus it was,
A match between his daughter and my son,
No sooner motioned but it was agreed,
And they no sooner saw but wooed and liked,
They have it sought to cross, and cross it thus.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Fie mistress Barnes and mistress Goursey both,
The greatest sin wherein your souls may sin,
I think is this, in crossing of true love,
Let me persuade ye.

sp.speaker: Mis. Bar.
sp.l: Sir, we are persuaded,
And I and mistress Goursey are both friends,
And if my daughter were but found again,
Who now is missing, she had my consent,
To be disposed off to her own content.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: I do rejoice, that what I thought to do,
Ere I begin, I find already done,
Why this will please your friends at Abington,
Franke, if thou seekst that way, there thou shalt find
Her, whom I hold the comfort of thy mind.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: He shall not seek me, I will seek him out,
Since of my mothers grant I need not doubt.

sp.speaker: Mi. Bar
sp.l: Thy mother grants my girl, and she doth pray,
To send unto you both a joyful day,

sp.speaker: Hodge.
sp.p:
Nay mistress Barnes, I wish her better, that those
joyful days may be turned to joyful nights.

sp.speaker: Coome.
sp.p:
Faith it is a pretty wench, and it is pity but she should
have him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
And mistress Mary, when ye go to bed, God send
you good rest, and a peck of Fleas in your nest, every one as
big as Francis.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well said wisdom, God send thee wise children.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.l: And you more money.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye, so wish I.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p:
It will be a good while, ere you wish your skin full of
bullet holes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Franke, hark ye? brother, now your wooing is done:
The next thing now you do, is for a son:
I prithee, for Ifaith I should be glad,
To have myself called nuncle, and thou Dad,
Well sister, if that Francis play the man,
My mother must be Grandam and you Mam,
to it FRancis, to it sister, God send ye joy,
it is fine to sing dansey my own sweet boy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well sir Jest on.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay sir, do you Jest on.

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Well may she prove a happy wife to him.

sp.speaker: M. Gou.
sp.l: And may he prove as happy unto her.

sp.speaker: S. Raph.
sp.l: Well Gentlemen, good hap betide them both,
Since it was my hap thus happily to meet.
To be a witness of this sweet contract,
I do rejoice, wherefore to have this joy
Longer present with me, I do request
That all of you will be my promised guests,
This long nights labour doth desire some rest,
Besides this wished end, therefore I pray,
Let me detain ye but a dinner time:
Tell me I pray, shall I obtain so much,

sp.speaker: M. Bar.
sp.l: Gentle sir Raphe, your courtesy is such,
As may impose command unto us all,
We will be thankful bold at your request.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I pray sir Raph, what cheer shall we have?

sp.speaker: S. Rap.
sp.l: Ifaith country fare, mutton and veal,
Perchance a duck or goose.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: O I am sick.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How now Mall, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Father and mother if you needs would know,
He named a goose, which is my stomachs foe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, come, she is with child of some odd jest,
And now she is sick till that she brings it forth.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A jest quoth you? well brother if it be,
I fear it will prove an earnest unto me,
Goose said ye sir? o that same very name,
Hath in it much variety of shame,
Of all the birds that ever yet was seen,
I would not have them graze upon this green,
I hope they will not, for this crop is poor,
And they may pasture upon greater store,
But yet it is pity that they let them pass,
And like a Common bite the Muses grass.
Yet this I fear if Franke and I should kiss,
Some creaking goose would chide us with a hiss,
I mean not that goose that sings it knows not what,
it is not that hiss when one says hist come hither,
Nor that same hiss when one says hist come hither,
Nor that same hiss that by a fire doth stand,
And hisseth T. or F. upon the hand,
But it is a hiss, and I will unlace my cote,
For I should sound sure if I heard that note,
And then green Ginger for the green goose cries,
Serves not the turn, I turned the white of eyes,
The Rosasolis yet that makes me live,
Is favour that these Gentlemen may give,
But if they be displeased, then pleased am I,
To yield myself a hissing death to die.
Yet I hope here is none consents to kill,
But kindly take the favour of good will.
If anything be in the pen to blame,
Then here stand I to blush the writers shame,
If this be bad, he promises a better,
Trust him, and he will prove a right true debtor.
